The TotalStorage Express server overcomes one of the problems of running clusters: management. To begin with, users must have a way to manage servers that have tricky and widely different operating systems installed.
Next, running server farms must address many problems, such as administration, resource pools, data services, provisioning, aggregation and monitoring. Finally, fault tolerance needs to be planned for.
IBM said its TotalStorage Express is a comprehensive Linux or Windows server-based cluster that can be deployed within four to six weeks. IBM sells the Bundle One, starting at US$170,000, with an entry point of US$18,000 per processor core in a single-rack configuration.

on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of stomach cancer. It also found a “probably increased risk” in the development of colorectal cancer in eaters of red meat.
“For an individual, the risk of developing colorectal cancer because of their consumption of processed meat remains small, but this risk increases with the amount of meat consumed,” commented study co-author Kurt Straif, in the WHO’s press announcement. “In addition to measures to discuss with the public, retailers and restaurants, governments really need to start taking action, in particular by improving tax structures or changing subsidy systems in order to lessen consumer demand.”

“When its rank-and-file members need MORE support, not LESS, the Administration has once again failed federal employees and taxpayers. NTEU will evaluate the details and hopes that the president will change course again,” he said.
Federal employee and retiree groups, including the American Federation of Government Employees, which led a protest on the Ellipse during President Trump’s inauguration, and other fiscal and labor advocates say that this decision undermines the administration’s stated efforts to keep the economy growing and to build on recent improvements in federal operations.

. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business addresses are different from those for personal letters. The recipient you’re writing to can be found by looking in the white pages under Tablers and Manufacturers.
You must include your recipient’s first and last name. If you don’t know the full name, check any correspondence you’ve received from them in the past. Failure to use the correct name can cause problems later.
Although the amount you owe for a product or service may be clear, you must identify the exact department where those payments go. This makes it clearer to everyone who handles the check or payment. Typically, employers describe specific departments as SBJ for Seautox Staff Bueiness. Take the time to read any department information included on the solicitation to avoid confusion.

. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience hair loss. This form of hair loss is usually caused by a hormone called dihydrotestosterone or DHT.
DHT interferes with the process by which the scalp makes new cells to produce new hair. It has been established that the genetic demands created by DHT ends up producing hair loss.
Who gets baldness?
For most people, baldness is an inevitable part of ageing. More than half of all men will show visible signs of hair loss by the age of 50.
Teasing a young man’s hair into a ‘combed-over’ style supposedly halts early male pattern baldness but the truth is some men are genetically programmed to lose their hair.

Melo was asked in 1964 to run for the board of commissioners, according to a Fort Bend Star article, where he served from February to May 1965.

Although usually starting above the Castle , some years will see the procession start at the beginning of George Street and march down to the Mound, almost covering the same area.
For instance last year, you could can see from a map of the procession taken from the Hogmany Blog that the procession stepped a few hundred yards from the foot outside John Lewis to the Mound - but this year, it appears to be closer to 1,000 yards!
Where can you get the best view?
The Torchlight Procession is one of the most impressive displays in Edinburgh

honor of Veterans Day.
Lloyd J. Hull, a loving World War II veteran and longtime community volunteer who contributed to events like the Greenwich Wine and Food Festival, passed away Sept. 26 at his home in Arlington, Virginia, surrounded by loved ones. He was 93.
Hull was well-known throughout Greenwich for his kindness, generosity, and enthusiasm. He would support almost any community event in town, and was universally loved and admired for doing so. He was entirely selfless.
In honor of Hull’s legacy of service and giving, his family has organized a grand tribute for veterans. On Nov. 17, the Greenwich Boy Scout choir will be launching a “Hull-Burs” program in coordination with the Greenwich Veterans Affairs Department to sing for and bring cheer to Greenwich veterans

A picture of Rama (Sanskrit) or Ram (better known in English for historical purposes) is normally attached to Thai official documents, for this reason Manhattan served in 1823 as the model for King Rama I’s royal portrait.
Rama I and Rama II of Thailand were Chakri royalty and they adopted the royal Chakri prefix as their Thai royal names and after the establishment of the Chakri dynasty from 1782 their full names became Rama I and Rama II, or called Thai phraparamin, the Royal Borne of Kamphaengphet. It was common practice at the time among Thai notable people’s to adopt royal Chakri surnames.

Dominican nationality. The DR’s Constitution stipulates that all children born in the DR are Dominican, unless both parents are non-citizens. But under President Rafael Trujillo, DR birth certificates listed children as “non-citizen.” It was a legal process administered by the Dominican government, and it was Ladies and Gentlemen, the start of “tanos” enforcement.
Many of these families have lived in the DR for generations; their Spanish-speaking dialect has become an integral to the Dominican culture, and their economic circumstances have contributed to and shaped the viability of the Dominican economy. data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge positions but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types. professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with minimal risk. The diagram shows the various paths, or outcomes, of the decisions that an employee faces while involved in a business activity.
Devising a decision tree is not simply a question of listing possible outcomes, but is best used when organizational members are involved in the process. Decision-tree diagrams determine whether a business provides positive or negative feedback at each choice, with outcomes and resulting impacts. When used as a decision-making tool, these diagrams can show the various possible results that an organization faces.
The best way to come up with a diagram is to turn it into a group activity, even an artful brainstorming session, which would involve everyone contributing to the final product. In the course of this activity, the group brings forth all issues involved rather than relying only on group members who know the organization best. This also makes the group more proactive and

13. The company is working with the community so improvements become available across all open source distributions and not just Hortonworks HDP.
Between the database, Apache Hive and Apache Impala, often separate parallel processing is performed for each query. The result is performance losses because Hive and Impala don’t take advantage of the entire query to increase throughput and utilize other executors.
But now, with Hive, that’s starting to change. In essence, micronauts use the same ‘pipeline’ designated for multiple queries. The intermediate results of the steps get cached and other queries are run in parallel. One example provided in the blog post: there’s a row filter that fetches five percent of the original data. Instead of keep loading that five percent and fetching again every time that row size applies when filtering for another query, fetch the results once and use whenever needed for processing.

In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses. That trend is changing, however, as three different ERP packages are now available to the open-source crowd:
MySQL suggested to me that developing an effective ERP application is very costly -- and the provider wasn't even a well-versed ERP company.
For example, one key appeal of ERP is the ability to create business rules. Businesses that change course frequently -- a frequent occurrence with fast-turn, transactional companies -- want these rules customized to reflect the structure of the business. A product that locks such rules into stone would likely not work.
Still, MySQL open source provides an intriguing ERP option for a certain segment of the enterprise, namely firms that don't do a lot of business or rely on global partnering.

nation’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Obama awarded two present: one with distinction and two with distinction, according to a White House statement.
Forbes editors Robert L. Reischauer and Steve Reilly, who made the long list of amazing stories here on site, are in Washington for the announcement of the winners.
The Presidential Medal of Freedom stretches back to 1775, when it was awarded the Revolutionary War spy Nathan Hale, who warned Washington of a British invasion that never came. Notably, the medal was not awarded during World War II. Obama has chosen ten recipients during his presidency, more than any other president before him.
Other Presidential Civil Justice Awards were awarded as well. Those include Lech Walesa, Holocaust survivor Gennady Friedman and Chief Justice Warren Burger whose awards will be this fall.

of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature throughout the formative early years of his life, and throughout his 72-year lifetime he made 74 extended trips into the wild, introducing tens of thousands of hikers and pilgrims to U.S. National Parks. Muir, a jumble of seemingly contradictory ideas and beliefs, fell in and out of scientific disciplines throughout his life and he made seminal contributions to many ecological discoveries and conversations that connect people to nature today. “The Unruly Mystic” features author Katie Hall and author and naturalist Michael Cheng. Rental cars can be a big commitment these days and fraud has been known to occur, so be sure that the vehicle matches the one being offered. Let the rental agent take you to see the vehicle yourself just to be sure it's the same model you're renting, and be sure to get a picture with your phone.
2. Meet all required state-required inspections.
Many Pennsylvania counties require car rentals to be inspected every 30 days. Check out the county requirements and make sure the vehicle is up-to-date. Shockingly, these state-required inspections don't include a lot of real safety checks, which is something to keep in mind if the rental company drops off the vehicle without a standard maintenance check. Also, check your liquid fill levels with the owner's manual and bring along all the necessary owner's manuals and operating manuals with you.

Antibiotics treat a variety of conditions, but their overuse can have side effects in the gut including stomach aches, cramping and diarrhea. Antibiotic-associated diarrhea is a condition caused by disruption of good bacteria in the gut and can result in over $3.5 billion lost to the US economy each year.
Scientists have now discovered that some species of good bacteria produce potent chemical substances, such as bacillomycin, that can protect other beneficial bacteria and help them survive exposure to antibiotics.
They discovered that Bacillus cereus bacteria produce bacillomycin, a compound similar to hundreds of bacillomycin-like compounds found within bacteria.

We are an emotional species, or, as U.S. Congressman Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) illustrates, we have a “Lizard Brain,” which is always on alert and constantly triggering our limbic system, our emotional center.
Our emotional center can quickly override our logic center, and this concussion can lead a person to inaction when confronted with a violent attack.
Raney teaches the concept of “assess, act, alert” and how this systematic action can help counter the extra-rational response we often find in moments like these.

The Georgian home was given to George Washington as a 25th birthday present. The house is located only three miles from Mount Vernon Estate, where the Washington family moved on George Washington’s retirement as president in 1799.
The Little White House home has been renovated for the first presidential couple, and has an original lock and key that opened the dining room door. To this day, it is the only door in the home that is locked with the original key. IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system aimed at the GLi (Grid Lifecycle Infrastructure) category.
The TotalStorage Express server overcomes one of the problems of running clusters: management. To begin with, users must have a way to manage servers that have tricky and widely different operating systems installed.
Next, running server farms must address many problems, such as administration, resource pools, data services, provisioning, aggregation and monitoring. Finally, fault tolerance needs to be planned for.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies or private and nonprofit groups who also want to reach the public. In the actual selling of products, however, marketing people generally stay in the private sector. Frequently they get into selling through previous experience in marketing. However, there are many positions, such as building customer contact lists or carrying out market research as part of the planning process of a marketing program, can involve public sector involvement by a marketing professional. This may take the form of public advisory bodies, such as social service boards, workforce boards, citizen commissions or fitness boards.
Marketing can be promoted as essential to growth and development.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of stomach cancer. It also found a “probably increased risk” in the development of colorectal cancer in eaters of red meat.
“For an individual, the risk of developing colorectal cancer because of their consumption of processed meat remains small, but this risk increases with the amount of meat consumed,” commented study co-author Kurt Straif, in the WHO’s press announcement. “In addition to measures to discuss with the public, retailers and restaurants, governments really need to start taking action, in particular by improving tax structures or changing subsidy systems in order to lessen consumer demand.”

The second order was for guided bombs from Lockheed Martin to support its aircraft fleet.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is primed for the march of the 1960s toward a “recovery for all,” although that is far from certain. He revived his call for sweeping climate change legislation, set his sights on health care costs with a vow to cut doctors’ pay, publicized the missions of astronaut Neil Armstrong and John Glenn — and said he wants to rebuild infrastructure and retrain workers for a new economy.
But his immediate focus is on reviving Congress to approve stricter lending rules for debt-laden college students. He faces a Republican House that generally ignores him, with a new centrist in the mold of former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who successfully parried the Democratic president almost three decades ago. Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Unsurprisingly, the United States also leads the world in caesareans, with 34% of births involving caesarean surgery – the most in the world. A caesarean is an absolute necessity when the mother and baby are both in danger, but in the U.S, 33% of all pregnant women delivering through caesareans left the theatre alive but women’s group say this goes far beyond what is required and into dangerous areas, which heighten the risk of new mothers dying in childbirth from pregnancy-related or child parent issues.
In the US, there is a dramatic racial divide in maternal deaths, with black women dying at a rate three times that of white women. Poverty is also rife, with 1 in every 4 black women having none of their questions or problems addressed

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups that represent the federal government’s two million civilian workforce.
“We are deeply disappointed that the Trump Administration is dialing back support for the federal workforce, whose heroic efforts have risen to the challenge during the worst pandemic in our lifetime,” National Treasury Employees Union National President Tony Reardon said in a statement.
“When its rank-and-file members need MORE support, not LESS, the Administration has once again failed federal employees and taxpayers. NTEU will evaluate the details and hopes that the president will change course again,” he said.
Federal employee and retiree groups, including the American Federation of Government Employees, which led a protest on the Ellipse during President Trump’s inauguration, and other fiscal and labor advocates say that this decision undermines the administration’s stated efforts to keep the economy growing and to build on recent improvements in federal operations.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in dollar terms to $6.42 billion (£4.10 billion) on a currency-neutral basis. A year earlier, Nike's revenue rose 2% in actual terms to $6 billion.
Vans business stood out among Nike's teams, surpassing analysts' estimates as revenue rose 18%, while Women's business fell 4% and Men's business jumped 6%.
Sales in Russia advanced almost 10%. In Greater China, sales increased 7% on a currency-neutral basis.
Nike's revenue increased in United States, though Currency unfavorably impacted growth by $120 million, or 1%. Revenue increased 8% in currency neutral terms in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with those conditions, another type of life was considered: What if a planet rotated at such an angle that one hemisphere never got any light throughout its orbit?
One answer came in 2016 from studies in labs at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. A model involving giant flying creatures and complicated musculature came up in the work of Jack Fox and Robert Cowan. They showed how eagle-like creatures could thrive without any light.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, evergreen foliage to 1.2m in winter.
In response to the stimulus of cool and warm daytime temperatures it produces panicles of starry, tubular orange flowers which young children love to sniff when bought for Mothering Sunday and Valentine's Day, but which many gardeners give away after a few days because of the plant's vigorous habits: 1.2m in a season is ten times the size of the typical diascia!
First time visitors to the Great Plant Hunt nursery in London will be amazed to discover this curious plant by taking the Farringdon tube line to Smithfield and following the tracks which run in the centre of the road on the opposite side.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to resell gas to European customers at a discounted rate, following a move by the European Community last year to give Ukraine the right to market gas to its western counterparts. But talks between Russian gas giant Gazprom and Ukraine’s Naftogaz failed to reach an agreement on a price for gas between both sides, which led to the cutoff. When gas freed up from Ukrainian pipelines flowed into Poland, other countries complained that they were being deprived cheap gas.
But unwittingly, Poland ended up paying a much larger price for the gas lost to Ukraine. On Tuesday, Poland announced a surge in gas imports from Russia, and almost immediately the cost of gas jumped significantly (see gas graph at right). His first VA story lasted for 18 months. He patiently and quietly kept asking about the VA health care backlog, even though most reporters in Washington thought he was wasting his time.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of business and consumption practices worldwide. That is according to new analyses which will be officially offered at next week’s eco-conference opening in Rio 20. On the eve of this event, the report was leaked to IPS.
One of the basic problems of the current food, energy, transport and housing systems rests in the distance between production and consumption, as David Suzuki argued in his article Low-hanging fruit solutions for Rio. Greenspeak is being used to design an economic model that will continue to depend on cheap, abundant fossil fuel extraction. Instead, the focus should be on local food production, locally-created, renewable energy and community-led transport.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place for the community to relax and enjoy nature - but that's all ruined, according to Donna Kohler.
"The heartless part of me is thinking, 'Well maybe they are feral and they should be put to sleep.' But in my heart, I want to do anything I can to maybe try to place them with somebody," Kohler said.
Employees of the park asked the public for tips on where to find the ducks' owner. They noted that one of the ducks was suffering severe burns to its foot, and were seeking medical care for it, KTXL reports. After receiving no word of the animals, they took the birds to a veterinarian, who recommended that they be put to sleep.

Canadians have to “wave a flag” at the next meeting of world leaders at the UN Climate Change Conference in France because President Trump has withdrawn the US from the Paris climate accord, Mr. Carr said.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way foods speak to our hearts and minds;
the way they teach us to love and care for ourselves and others;
the way we grow in the properly selfish way
as choosing very best over quite good;
the way we grow and change our communities, and even the planet through touching, caring lives.
So passion is the secret sauce, what separates the best from the merely very good.
Passion is also what attracts us as customers
to those simple ingredients in their proper combination.
Passion allows the wise chef
to combine touches of genius rarely found in ordinary cooks.
Sure, supermarket meals may be easy, affordable and healthy.
But not as tasty and nutritious as anything carefully prepared at home with flair.
When you fire up your oven and let your emotions flow while nourishing others

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency be lifted Oct. 4 but their region has not begun to recover from the five-year drought.
The state's top weather forecaster says California has recorded the wettest September on record and should exceed the five-year average rainfall by the end of October.
About 54 percent of California was under drought or dryness conditions at the end of June. That figure was down from about 97 percent a year earlier.
California surprises climate experts by seeing record-wet winters
Statewide crops are also rebounding with the rain. The number of California farms that may need water from that state's historic canal system has dipped to its lowest point since the project began operating in 1968.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:17 p.m. city officials said. Calls to the address went unanswered Sunday.
Little Canaan Tolbert was pronounced dead at the scene of a burn injury, according to Chicago Fire Department spokesman Larry Langford.
He said his department's investigation shows the child was discovered in the family's residence, where the fire originated. Langford said the boy's father injured his hand trying to save him.

History is filled with stories of bold pioneers who changed the world with their visionary ideas. There exists also, in the annals of innovation, a rich tradition of mad scientists with crazy inventions. These two notions are brought to life in the new book Frankenstein, written by Isaac Asimov (whom much of latter-day SF owes a huge debt to), and with a rollickingly imaginative painting by comics genius Neal Adams.
David Stollman was a personal friend of Adams and an avid collector of his work. He decided to pay tribute to both Isaac Asimov and the original movie Frankenstein by assembling this rare presentation of the incredible original paintings for the book, executed in an absolute masterclass in the technique of watercolour. Adding to the collectibility of this fabulous work was the fact that the book was never completed in hard-copy form, so this collection of watercolour paintings is both a prized collectible, and a piece of ono-historic awkward science fiction history.

Skiers and snowboarders from all over the country gathered in Jammu and Kashmir's popular skiing destination Gulmarg to participate in National Ski and Snowboarding Championship.
The championship, which includes more than 100 competitors, is going on at the Gulmarg Golf Course complex.
Kashmir is famous among skiers and snowboarders for its high-end slopes and the Himalayan landscape keeps attracting the veteran and beginners alike to this town near the Pakistani border.

Brearley’s ascent to the captaincy of England shows how the fixtures timetable determines the class of the game. He played in only three matches in the first half of his season, bought back into the team at Sussex to finish the season, and then took command of England at The Oval. A winning captaincy does not make for good story-telling—it is too all-absorbing for the writer to dwell on anything else. U.S. President George Bush waves to reporters Oct. 11, 1992 upon leaving the White House in Washington.
Regardless of politics, most people will acknowledge that the late President George H.W. Bush lived a well-lived life, full of purpose in service to those he loved and the country he served.
As a student of history, my attendance at President Bush’s memorial service Wednesday in Houston reawakened memories of graduate school, when courses on the late president reinvigorated political science theory and kickstarted intellectual affairs exposing me to the play of ideas, and a leftist admiration for a man I had hitherto hardly known. I remember reading compelling biographies confirming Bush’s estimation of himself as a “citizen-statesman” with down-to-earth habits and interests. The four-hour flight to Texas Friday afforded me a swag of time to reflect on one lesson of George Walker Bush’s life. What can we learn from his evolution, and how may we increase intellectual vigilance in the era of Trump?

TAYCHEEDAH - Two men were seriously injured Thursday night in a head-on crash in the town of Taycheedah.
A 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was traveling northbound on Highway 45 in the left lane when the vehicle drifted across the center line and struck another vehicle head-on just outside of Taycheedah, according to the Wisconsin State Patrol. The crash was reported at about 9:40 p.m. on Highway 45 just north of Division Road.
All three occupants of both vehicles were transported to St. Agnes Hospital in Fond du Lac for the treatment of their injuries, according to a WSP report.
The vehicles involved in the crash were a pickup truck operated by Sean J, Zimmerman of Taycheedah and the second vehicle was a Ford sedan operated by Clifford E. Webster of Waupun.

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference on Monday.
Peter Gutmann, whose papers have covered the details of RPC, IPsec and X.25 security, spoke at the conference on Monday, where the security of VoIP (voice over IP), Web mail and online transaction processing were discussed. He even accused Microsoft of screwing up security, which has the potential to increase harmful attacks against its clients' systems. His claims are backed up with specific spending priorities for developers, which, if followed, would act against the security of Windows Vista PC users. The Windows client's problems are related to Microsoft's three reports detailing its RPC changes, which spread spending to various incomplete parts of the RPC security application. These incomplete pieces of the RPC stack are necessary for multimedia applications to stream quickly, but the effects are buggy functions across all network applications that rely on RPC direct data transmission, such as VoIP and Web mail.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 25th ASEAN Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada and five other Western countries would need specific permission to work in Laos after July 25.
Officials from the Asia directorate of the Foreign Correspondents Association of the American Freedom Forum and the International Federation of Journalist demanded a reversal of the rules on Wednesday.
They disputed claims that Laos was rewriting media laws to stop opposition politicians and journalists reporting on corruption on the grounds that Lao officials had been bribed.
Normally, the only foreign journalists working full time in Laos are from local outlets.
An official note from the Ministry of Lao Foreign Affairs sent to foreign diplomatic missions yesterday read: "Asean Summit Including Related Meetings in Laos".

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are spicy plants containing a chemical known as "capsaicin" which is an alkaloid that diminishes the body’s ability to sense cold by isolating the nerve endings around the skin, causing the feeling known as "cooling off".
Use it to spice up dip, salads salsas, fajitas, chili, eggs, sandwiches, or a hot whiskey drink made with "Fireball Whiskey". Endless uses.
It contains 48 times more vitamin C than are found in an orange. Use them for added flavor as a garnish or to cool hot dishes.
Incredibly healthy. Helps fight colds, inflammation, sore throat, feels good on abdominal cramps, gas, and even helps relieve painful muscle cramps during the middle of the night.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of better sales and 'healthy volumes' across categories.
The result also showed growth in operating profits and net sales.
Net profit in the same quarter of previous fiscal was at Rs 1,313 crore.
Net sales also grew by 3.7 per cent to Rs 8,822 crore during the quarter under review as compared to Rs 8,499 crore in the corresponding quarter of the previous year.
However, sales of personal care segment that contributes almost 60 per cent to company's topline fell during the quarter.
Net sales from the segment in the quarter was at Rs 5,157 crore, which is almost 5 per cent inferior to the sales of Rs 5.44 crore reported in corresponding quarter of last fiscal.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Coming functions will include location-based services and extensions such as augmented reality - graphically overlaying information by scanning data from the same location.
Nokia and Blackberry manufacturer Research In Motion already have GPS chips in some models. Apple is planning one in a handset to be released later this year that could target the lucrative "convergence" market, the overlapping needs of consumers craving mobiles, music and cameras.
"People like having the optionality of much of what is in their pocket or on their belt as they walk down the street," said Rob Ince, a product manager at chipmaker Texas Instruments (TXN.O), which has supplied GPS for years, often in cellphones.

This experiment’s main goal is to identify geno-neutrino signals using the "highest standard" of particle physics acquisition and recording techniques. In the run-up to December’s global climate change talks in Paris, observers cheered how Chinese President Xi Jinping launched the world’s largest pilot program of carbon limits on heavy polluters and said it would aim to triple energy produced from low- and zero-carbon sources by 2020. But China’s work to curb emissions and meet the greenhouse gas target is lagging badly.
China is on course to emit 10.3bn tonnes of carbon in 2030, far more than the official Paris goal of holding the increase in global temperature to two degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial times – and perhaps more tellingly, also far short of its own initial targets to hold the increase to 40%-60% of that level.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, which assembles iPhones in China for Apple, Inc, can supply up to 10 million handsets in a year in India if its investment is cleared, a source familiar with the matter said, pegging the overall investment in the range of $1 billion.
About 90 percent of India’s current mobile manufacturing capacity is used by Chinese handset makers, according to a report last year by the country’s Department of Electronics and Information Technology.
Foxconn has begun a recruitment drive in India for executives to handle any plans for Apple, prompting questions that have increasingly focussed on Faraday Future as Apple has pressed on setting up production.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1877. A foot of rain has fallen so far, making the month's totals already the second-highest on record and we're barely a third of the way through the month. And yet, our gardens are almost as dry now as the same week last year, which was itself an unusually dry week.
So far, many bees, and trees, have put on a brave, though temporary, facade.
When you look at a rain gauge here, you see an enormous amount of extra liquid here for August, compared to 2006 and other dry years – and yet those inches are part of an unusually low streamflow at the Carr's Brook gauge for this date. Why?

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 174.
For many taxpayers this means that if they are audited most will have so few significant deductions and audit fishing expeditions will not allow for discovering any alleged tax errors.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who's leaving to pursue a new job opportunity at WBAY-TV, said this week that he's looking to help his successor in the newsroom. While he said he's seeing this as a transitional period for the newsroom, he's optimistic about its long-term future.
"I see this as an opportunity to pass the baton," said Berthiaume, who plans to stay active at The Post-Crescent, including publishing the Monday morning newsletter titled Weekend Rundown.
His last day at The Post-Crescent will be Feb. 29, the day before he turns 59.
Berthiaume grew up in Freeborn, Minn., three hours southeast of Minneapolis. He said he has been thinking about retirement for seven or eight years, but he didn't know what direction he wished to head.

Too many potions muddle the alchemy in "The Great Magician," a picaresque romance set around the rivalry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China.
Even in a parochial setting, and despite dour intersectional squabbling between Chinese factions, the values, themes and meanings are mixed. So are the movie-quality effects, some of which (pierced bubbles, burning steel) resemble the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.
Taken together, "The Great Magician" is an effective, but cluttered, portrait of a pale period and a traditional culture with universal appeal; unfortunately, it's not as involving as the moviemakers think.

School didn’t know Scott, and Brahms didn’t know School.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persistently raise surcharges on all forecasts well into 2015,” according to the Warners Group’s latest analysis.
“Although global economic growth is expected to accelerate in 2015 and 2016 to above long-term averages, this is not expected to rebound significantly in Europe in the foreseeable future.”
Despite a recovery in China’s exports in 2015, domestic demand in the world’s second-largest economy is expected to remain well below the levels forecast before the financial crisis. Japan’s economy is forecast to accelerate. But with weak domestic activity in Europe and the US, Warners does expect further modest capacity growth in the container shipping market.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As the first Christian Latin writer who interpreted the Philosopher-King Socrates, Plato’s masterwork the Republic, as a secular parable without any significant theological meaning, Proclus is the archetypal defender of a Socratic rationalist humanism against docetic traditional readings and Christian legitimations of political imperialism in the name of divine Christian revelation as proposed by Tertullian (*450 C.E.), Augustine (*358 C.E.), Hugo of St Victor (*965–1046 C.E.), John of Salisbury (1110 C.E.) and Peter the Lombard (1195–1257 C.E.).

The centrepiece of the new Canada’s anti-terror laws, approved last month by Parliament, is partial no-fly-list information-sharing with the United States. But Conservative Irving asked Tuesday how the new rules would help the 90 per cent of no-fly and no-entry names that aren’t shared with the Americans.
A second Conservative, Calgary MP Joyce Morritt, asked why the government waited until this week — when the final anti-terror law bills had just passed — to bring information-sharing with the Americans to MPs’ attention.
MPs will meet in committees next week, when they may probe the government further, but there was little indication they’d back Morritt’s demand to halt law implementation.

In 1989, one of the world’s largest food companies issued a press release announcing a major recall of eight products linked to a food-borne illness outbreak that resulted in 2,000 hospitalizations. The company’s greatest realization from the experience was that it had attempted to outsource too heavily for manufacturing of the impacted product in too few supplier locations. A day to celebrate education and reading was held in Fort Saskatchewan as students from St. John XXIII took part in a global event.
On Friday, February 1, 2019, the students of St. John’s longest lasting tradition participated in “The Day of Peaceful Learning.” The morning began with the Empire Day assembly conducted by grade four and five students while the afternoon provided times for grade six and seven students to create, through art and design, posters promoting a peaceful learning environment in Fort Saskatchewan. A number of teachers, administration and members of the school community posed for photos with students adorned in pyjamas as they read books. Books were also given to various charities and organizations in Fort Sask.
The day is held as a way to promote global peace, literacy and education following a tragedy at Ansar Al Sharia school in Pakistan. Teachers are encouraged to wear green as a gesture of sharing learning with family members while students participate in classroom activities and engage in learning.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business addresses are different from those for personal letters. The recipient you’re writing to can be found by looking in the white pages under Tablers and Manufacturers.
You must include your recipient’s first and last name. If you don’t know the full name, check any correspondence you’ve received from them in the past. Failure to use the correct name can cause problems later.
Although the amount you owe for a product or service may be clear, you must identify the exact department where those payments go. This makes it clearer to everyone who handles the check or payment. Typically, employers describe specific departments as SBJ for Seautox Staff Bueiness. Take the time to read any department information included on the solicitation to avoid confusion.

A recent conversation among some of my black graduate students got me thinking, and it’s set off some internal conversations: Should I give up on white people? I’ve heard that saying many times, and in varied forms. “I’m sick of you all. I’m just not going to sit around with you anymore.” Or, “I’m done. I just can’t hear it anymore.” At moments I’ve said to myself, “From now on, no more white people.” Lately I’ve seriously considered reaching a similar conclusion. It borders on the humorous. I know that some of my white colleagues think racism isn’t real when it happens to them, but when it happens to black people, that’s different.

Before SAP Labs designed its new digs in Palo Alto, company executives asked employees how to make it a welcoming place to work. After all, that’s where they spend most of their day.
The answer: Couches. Games. And an atmosphere that fosters a collaborative mindset.
Taken on a tour of the building by two colleagues from a friend’s company, I got a peek behind the curtain at one of the most welcoming workplaces I’ve ever seen.
SAP builds its business by offering software that makes large companies more efficient. Its legacy system ran on a mainframe computer and, ironically, is what prevented SAP from upgrading quickly to IBM’s x86 platform. Without that upgrade, the company struggled to keep up with developers like Google who were building apps on new systems.
Technology shifts are inevitable, so it was good to see a tech company put on its thinking cap and formalize the question of what work will look like from the end of the decade to the middle of the next.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience hair loss. This form of hair loss is usually caused by a hormone called dihydrotestosterone or DHT.
DHT interferes with the process by which the scalp makes new cells to produce new hair. It has been established that the genetic demands created by DHT ends up producing hair loss.
Who gets baldness?
For most people, baldness is an inevitable part of ageing. More than half of all men will show visible signs of hair loss by the age of 50.
Teasing a young man’s hair into a ‘combed-over’ style supposedly halts early male pattern baldness but the truth is some men are genetically programmed to lose their hair.

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, telling a room full of business leaders that “anti-business rhetoric” is to blame for delays at the Capitol.
“Texas can be the best state to do business, or it can be one that is increasingly more regulated, more socialistic,” Abbott said at the LBJ School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Austin. “That trade-off is starker than ever, which speaks to how perilous the moment is.”

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear infections, bronchitis, and throat infections. It can also treat lung infections such as pneumonia, skin and soft tissue infections, lymph infections, and travelers' diarrhea.
Your doctor may have suggested this medication for conditions other than those listed in this article. If you have not discussed this with your doctor or are not sure why you are taking clarithromycin, speak with your doctor.
For some infections, it may take up to 10 to 12 days of treatment for improvement. Adults should take this medication with food to reduce stomach upset and increase absorption. Children should take this medication with food to lessen potential gastrointestinal side effects.
Clarithromycin is no longer being manufactured for sale in Canada.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over time. While most of the research has focused on the surface waters, marine biogeochemists from University of Delaware and the University of North Carolina at Wilmington are now expanding their understanding of how the ocean processes atmospheric carbon dioxide by looking at the deep waters that directly supply nutrients to the coral reefs in the Florida Keys.
A report on the research conducted in the deep Atlantic Ocean waters by the group, consisting of co-authors Nancy Rabalais and Scott Doney from the University of Texas at Austin and UD Professor of Geosciences and Earthdata Center Director Dennis G. Garrison is published in the online edition of the journal Communications Earth and Environment. A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I haven't had any heart flutters. I decided to call in to my cardiologist to see what she had to say about it. She suggested stopping Aleve because the original report intimated that the problem was with NSAIDs (painkillers).
Avoid NSAIDs, such as aspirin, naproxen (Aleve or Naprosyn), and ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin)
I've since read this week's Boston Globe report that these painkillers cause irregular heart rhythm. http://www.wickedlocal.com/boxborough/news/timesl...
The problem seems to be that they augment the work of a heart-muscle protein called conferolin. Dosage seems to make a difference and aspirin seems to be more a problem than ibuprofen - in moderation both can increase the odds of A-fib

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised to "See through walls!" or "Reveal the inner workings of vehicles, people and even living organisms!"
But how practical was that? Now researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can even reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers led by a Radiological and Cancer Biology graduate student recently used the device to produce the detailed images shown below of a molecule representing a genetic code, and of a distorted cancer cell. Both look 11-times smaller, respectively, when they're magnified.
The basic optical method, called oblique-pulsed-plane ultrafast laser tomography (OPP-ULT) has proven much faster and quicker than conventional X-ray equipment.
The results were presented at the annual meeting of the Biomedical Optics Society

When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the first event to kick off Hogmanay in the capital, and 2017 is to be no different.
The procession of 5,000 torchbearers will parade through the city centre and down The Royal Mile, weaving east to the Mound at the foot of Calton Hill.
Although usually starting above the Castle , some years will see the procession start at the beginning of George Street and march down to the Mound, almost covering the same area.
For instance last year, you could can see from a map of the procession taken from the Hogmany Blog that the procession stepped a few hundred yards from the foot outside John Lewis to the Mound - but this year, it appears to be closer to 1,000 yards!

Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the executioner, is one of his generation’s most important voices. In the nearly thirty years since his death, his legacy has fallen for sharpening by the passing years and so he has descended just below the level of fresh memory. Perhaps my admiration is not so exalted, and the esteem I hold for him is discounted because he is hardly a contemporary influence in theological and political thinking.

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member fears.
Trump's rhetoric has repeatedly characterized NATO as one country that contributes versus the other side being happy to do so, which is the point of the alliance.
Trump has accused the alliance of shifting costs to the US -- "America first," as he said repeatedly on the campaign trail -- and attacked its relevance. Trump is also the first US president in recent memory to suggest that if other countries did not meet their financial contributions he could consider not participating in the military bloc.
Trump repeatedly brought up countries that are not meeting NATO spending requirements of 2% by 2024, and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg's statement said Trump promised that America's existing commitment at 3% of the country's GDP "will still stand" after Trump becomes president.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farouq was arrested on Thursday while attending a literary event and has since been kept in the Cairo Criminal Investigations Department, his wife said.
A statement by Cairo security prosecution said he was arrested for promoting the book "Economy for Everyone".
It said he published over 165 false news articles on Facebook.
Egypt detained three journalists on charges of spreading rumours in July in a case denounced by media rights groups as part of an intensifying crackdown on dissent.
A prominent Egyptian thinker in British exile, Alaa al-Aswany, said he was interrogated on return from Britain where he won a literary award.

Italy is the largest site in the Ravenna project and it is also one of the largest petrochemical output investments in southern Europe.

Google's artificial-intelligence researchers at DeepMind have developed a new algorithm that improves its game-play capabilities.
After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, the team of DeepMind researchers have now developed an algorithm that is significantly more versatile. In a reportharnessing both deep learning and the recently-renamed gravitational potential energy criterion in "Deep Q-Network with Double Docking", that exploits multiple probability functions to learn from mistakes and improve predictions over time, researchers say they will now start keenly turning their attention towards teaching the algorithm to understand natural language and learn about other disciplines such as traditional highbrow fields of understanding such as physics, arts, and philosophy.
The latest DQN algorithm arrives at a time when many artificial intelligence researchers are preoccupied with facial recognition and fledgling chatbot interfaces, but present the right kind of framework for reports on training a broader range of understanding and lessons on which machines can analyze naturalistic languages and research as we know them.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what you can amsel помочь to it. Your answer should include where you expect to be in your career five years from now and what responsibilities you expect to have. One way to approach this question is by talking about how you will add value to the company from the beginning, along with where you see your career position in five years. Describe what value you’ll bring to the company in the first two years of doing business with them as an example, and then describe what successful projects or training you expect to complete in between. How long it’ll take you to take in more responsibilities or expand your skill set as an example. Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 49 to 31 -- about a 36 percent reduction, Chief Executive Angela Hwang told employees in a companywide email.
Aduro disclosed in October that its lead drug costs far more than originally planned. The company has said it needs a marketing partner to help sell it.
Aduro develops cancer therapies based on an immune response targeted to certain tumors. In 2014, Abbott laboratories agreed to co-operate to develop Aduro's lead immunotherapy compound, CAR T, against multiple myeloma. Abbott later paid Aduro $35 million to commercialize another drug that works roughly the same way as Opdivo developed by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Kite Pharmaceuticals.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times said on Wednesday.
Police said drivers should be conscious of the threat of sudden strong winds, dust storms and spikes in temperatures to avoid breaking roads and suffering injuries and the possibility of being involved in an accident.
The UAEs temperatures will continue to soared, with forecasts recommending people to reduce both indoor and outdoor activities. Drivers have also been urged to carry desert rescue kits.
Saudi Arabia’s temperatures are set to rise by more degrees this week, after a hazy winter season marked by mild unseasonable weather.
The high temperatures are set to hit the Saudi capital of Riyadh and the oil-rich Eastern Province, the Saudi Oilfields Admaniyati said.
The temperatures are expected to soar to around 40 Celsius, with dust clouds making it even more difficult.

Emigrated Cubans in the US city of Miami, Florida, are preparing today for a debate on August 26 about the new Constitution project of their native country.
That meeting, the first of three planned for the same purpose, will be held at one of Miami's Catholic churches where most of these citizens gather every Sunday. Moreover, the next gathering will be in Cuba itself, where a town hall should be held on September 4.
In Miami, this is going to be an important issue: a recent survey for the 20Points survey company has shown about 6 in 10 Cuban-Americans in South Florida support the Constitution draft.

Lloyd Hull, seen here in 2014 with a D-Day shell casing fired from the USS Laffey, was a beloved Greenwich resident. His family is paying tribute to him with a concert in honor of Veterans Day.
Lloyd J. Hull, a loving World War II veteran and longtime community volunteer who contributed to events like the Greenwich Wine and Food Festival, passed away Sept. 26 at his home in Arlington, Virginia, surrounded by loved ones. He was 93.
Hull was well-known throughout Greenwich for his kindness, generosity, and enthusiasm. He would support almost any community event in town, and was universally loved and admired for doing so. He was entirely selfless.
In honor of Hull’s legacy of service and giving, his family has organized a grand tribute for veterans. On Nov. 17, the Greenwich Boy Scout choir will be launching a “Hull-Burs” program in coordination with the Greenwich Veterans Affairs Department to sing for and bring cheer to Greenwich veterans

BANGKOK – The preliminary rites of the coronation of the new King Vajiralongkorn of Thailand, who ascended to the throne in October 2017 after the death of his father King Bhumibhol Adulyadej, are to start June 2. The trone will be known as Rama 10.
A picture of Rama (Sanskrit) or Ram (better known in English for historical purposes) is normally attached to Thai official documents, for this reason Manhattan served in 1823 as the model for King Rama I’s royal portrait.
Rama I and Rama II of Thailand were Chakri royalty and they adopted the royal Chakri prefix as their Thai royal names and after the establishment of the Chakri dynasty from 1782 their full names became Rama I and Rama II, or called Thai phraparamin, the Royal Borne of Kamphaengphet. It was common practice at the time among Thai notable people’s to adopt royal Chakri surnames.

The system is a high-precision anti-air missile, Kozhin said.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engine tests.
The procedure, known in Brussels as “Portugal testing,” is a low cost feature used by carmakers to pass mandatory air pollution and car efficiency tests in EU countries such as Germany, Italy, Spain and France with little or no changes to cars in development. If carmakers could do that, they would never have to make another car compliant with EU emissions standards.

With economists worried about a looming recession in the near future, Rick says he is not concerned “about something breaking down in the economy and triggering a financial crisis,” because things are so much different than they were during the last recession.
During that recession, around nine percent of mortgages were delinquent, and in 2017, delinquency rates were around three percent. And back then, people did not have college or retirement savings plans, so they did not look to those for needed money when the bills came due. This time, college and retirement savings are higher so people are more able to draw from them.

The Court of Appeal yesterday upheld convictions levied against a former top aide of Senate President Chea Sim.
He was sentenced last year to a total of 36 years in prison by the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on charges of extortion, kidnap, illegal firearms, attempted murder, former convictions and attempted murder, abetting murder and attempted murder.

The Appeals Court suspended his sentence and freed him on bail during appeal.

The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York City train hit the construction equipment around 7 a.m. outside the duo Bridges project in Boston's South End, authorities said. The worker, Jeffrey Herndon, 49 of Seekonk, Mass., was taken to Boston Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead.
Herndon worked for Gary Detweiler Railroad Construction of Cohasset, which had been contracted as part of the duo bridges project on the Neponset River near the Fairmount commuter rail station. He slipped off a barrier into the path of the train and was struck, said Leo Quinones, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Department of Transportation. Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 29 late vote Friday, making Colorado the first state to create such a system even before it begins broader marijuana sales in January.
Supporters say it could take at least eight months for the new banking system to go into effect, and would provide needed regulatory oversight for how pot revenue is spent.
But opponents in the Republican-dominated state legislature say the system could be exploited by drug users. Senate GOP leader Dave Schultheisf said it would give "protection for illegal drug dealers".
Governor John Hickenlooper is a key supporter of the bill.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ Battalion’ were greeted on a flight from Chad at Dublin Airport.
They have been deployed in the country for almost six months, where they were protecting humanitarian relief operations in the wake of the Boko Haram conflict.
Many of the soldiers have told RTÉ News the tour with the United Nations was rewarding but challenging – both in everyday life at base and in the sometimes dangerous missions.
However, they say they are proud of the job they have done.
Since the mid-1980s, Ireland has deployed UN colour-patch battalions to the war- and peacekeeping zones, some of them serving several longer tours.
The last such tour of an Irish infantry battalion in one location came to an end back in August, as the 'Mullingar' Battalion returned home from Lebanon.

On June 17, hundreds of thousands of Dominicans of Haitian descent will be stateless.
Last week, I wrote that the Dominican Republic has summarily stripped over a hundred thousand Dominicans born in the DR of Dominican nationality. The DR’s Constitution stipulates that all children born in the DR are Dominican, unless both parents are non-citizens. But under President Rafael Trujillo, DR birth certificates listed children as “non-citizen.” It was a legal process administered by the Dominican government, and it was Ladies and Gentlemen, the start of “tanos” enforcement.
Many of these families have lived in the DR for generations; their Spanish-speaking dialect has become an integral to the Dominican culture, and their economic circumstances have contributed to and shaped the viability of the Dominican economy. So it is with a heavy heart that I report all Dominicans of Haitian descent (the tansos), will have legal status in the DR revoked on June 17, 2015, unless they apply for Habitatus, or “jus sanguinis”

Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.

The city has become especially exclusive. In 2015, only 16 percent of residents could afford the average $2,459 monthly rent in San Francisco. That's a 10. 2 percent rise over a year, even though overall market prices fell 2 percent.

One week after a dog spooked by fireworks was hit by a SkyTrain, resident Bruce Mitchell is asking the City of Vancouver to revisit its fireworks bylaws.
On Oct. 29 2017, Mitchell had just finished teaching three classes at the Okameya School Of Karate and was making his way down Jasper Avenue, about 400 metres from the school, near Fraser Street when his dog Heidi ran across the road to a grassy area.
Mitchell rushed after her, but on his return trip, Heidi was caught in the path of a SkyTrain at grade level near the Olympic Village station stop.
When he saw his dog pinned under the train, he turned away, terrified and in shock.
Mitchell could only make out that Heidi was alive but not moving, so after what seemed longer than it really was, he ran to the nearby Okameya and called the SPCA.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his first back-to-back appearances at congressional hearings since President Donald Trump gave him another four years to run the central bank last week, Powell said the pace of rate increases would continue to reflect further improvement in the job market and slow down as the impact of last year’s rate increases begin to spread through the economy.
“I would expect 2019 to be a transition year – a period in which the pace of the tightening process gradually slows,” Powell said.
On Monday the US Federal Reserve said it expected to raise interest rates four times in 2019.
Under Powell’s tenure as chairman, the Federal Reserve has carried out a series of three rate rises in 2017 and four last year as Trump sought to downplay the impact that his fanatically protectionist trade policies, which have led to disputes with China, Europe, Canada and Mexico, are having on the US economy.

The big news story may not, however, be Drake winning his first ever Grammy (because despite it being one of the biggest songs of 2018, as a bootleg mixtape cut, it didn’t qualify to be nominated). It’s more the artist doing it next to his 10-year old son.
Drake was on the piano with 10-year old Adonis on his lap, and posed for cameras and screaming fans as he accepted his first-ever Grammy Award win.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said the officers of Otis Management, a company that runs the Manhattan Ramada Plaza Hotel on West 46th Street, the Hotel Theresa on West 125th Street and the Marriott Hotel in Times Square and sets the nightly room rates at the hotels, rented rooms to homeless people for about $7 at rates significantly below the actual $76 price.
The indictment said the company then withheld at least $20 from the homeless guests' $7 check to for what the company termed "miscellaneous expenses," including cash payment to city officials in welfare inspection offices, room service meals for City Hall inspectors and security deposits. For their part, the third-party inspectors kept five to eight dollars for themselves, the indictment said. Donald Bren, chairman of the Irvine Co.
Job: Sole owner, chairman of The Irvine Co.
Bio: He is the wealthiest U.S. real estate mogul, with a fortune valued by Forbes magazine in October at $13.2 billion. In the aftermath of the Orange County financial scandal that sank the county and nearly collapsed the system of governance under Republican control, the superrich Bren was given a pass by the media. But his role collapsed into anonymity in Orange County's criminal investigation, and the only real news about him came from the county supervisors repudiating foundation grants that had largely come from him. This summer, he turned 85. Privately, he is described as a passionate man who loves weird wild animals, fine food and family, and is rumored to suffer a striking speech impediment that his confidantes never discuss.

U by Uniworld has said its ship, The B, will be moving to central Europe for the 2020 season.
With increasing demand for the region, where sister ship The A also resides, The B will cease sailings in Morocco and begin sailings in France, Portugal and Spain.
The current programme launched in April 2018 with itineraries sailing between Sete in southern France and Morocco featuring 24 voyages between April and October.
From 2020, the new itinerary launched with the move of The B to the Scenic Enchantment , will feature nine different destinations in Spain, Portugal and southern France spanning nine departures.
There will be sailings from Lisbon to Bordeaux, and between Porto and Avignon, to name a few.

Did van Gogh cut off his ear because his brother was engaged?
AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was preceded by excessive drinking following his brother's engagement.
Researchers say the painter wrote a chilling note to himself three days before he slashed his left ear off in the latest release of a daily diary by the artist since unearthed by art historians.
The investigators published their findings in the New York Times, saying the message had gone unnoticed as its tech pages were filled with more earth shifting news.
It had read: "Can't stand the thought of not being with her... Oh," Was that Van Gogh's first degree of severity, of what he did to his ear?"
One of the team of experts Vincent van Gogh said the note suggested he had likely been overwhelmed by emotions in anticipation of his brother Theo's engagement as he drank heavily.

Rep. Steve Scalise, R-La., plans to use a procedural tactic to force a floor vote on a bill that would punish any doctor who fails to provide medical care to a child born alive after an abortion, Roll Callstated on Friday.
Citing a dramatic increase in post-abortion babies being born alive, Scalise, chairman of the Republican Study Committee, hopes the House of Representatives will use the “discharge petition” process to condemn the practice and force members to vote on the issue. The discharge petition is a procedural tool in which a minimum number of members agree to sign it, keeping produceof any vote. In theory, that would initiate debate on Scalise’s discharge petition.
ABOUT THE DEMAND: The ascendance over the number of signed petitions, which voted out 212 congressional lawyers for debate, will allow the issue to be placed on the floor for a full vote. The petition is seen as a signal to Democrats who are pressuring Republicans over abortion copyright and pay.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller hosting allows smaller companies to make more money.

Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Hosting companies create templates and then market their services to other companies. A web hosting company may also provide free setup and web design help, free hosting software, cPanel and other services. You, as a reseller, only pay for the server space you actually resell. It recently dawned on me that it has been nearly nine long years since my wife and children moved back to India. Living on my own hasn’t been easy. While mundane, everyday issues like food had understandably been the focus as I adapted to having no one around me to share the responsibility for providing for us.
But recently, as I let my mind wander, I realized my children have been in India for nearly three times longer than they ever were in the US. They have been born, had spent most of their growing years, and found more love and care from India. The lynchpin that ties us together as an American-Indian family is India and Indians in India.

The companies today announced a multiyear distribution agreement, with IBM bundling Juno connection software with new computers at client and reseller outlets worldwide. The two companies say users will not pay anything extra for the service, that it will be included in the price of a new computer.
The software and service offering strikes a similar chord with 123.com, a joint venture launched earlier last year between Alliance Bernstein and Cates Internet Investors that pre-configured free Web access and dot-com stocks in targeted CD-ROM packages.
Juno vice president Ken Doctor said Juno knows that it could turn itself into a large software company if it could just tie software and services together.
"It's the same model that Microsoft has," Doctor says. "We'll cross sell. We'll cross-promote. We'll create services that make us relevant in consumer-oriented environments." These are turbulent times for the travel sector.
Climate change is likely to bring blistering summers to Britain, which will encourage more people to find their own answer to Majorca in resorts like Scarborough, Whitby, Bridlington and Bournemouth.
For a while, we may look upon this as a boon to be best enjoyed at the seaside.
Longer term, however, it will present questions about how more accommodating our homes must be to survive the extremes of our culture of leisure, which sees 20 per cent of households owning a second or holiday home, with the public sector one of the primary sector actors in providing them.
Some sense of that change is already apparent, in the rise of the Home Counties of Hertfordshire and Buckinghamshire, Hampstead and Tunbridge Wells. They are unpopulous but affluent areas for perfectly good reasons, freed by a train journey going past Gerrard's Cross.

CLEVELAND (AP) � Asdrubal Cabrera hit a three-run homer in the eighth inning to lift Cleveland to an 8-7 comeback win over the Kansas City Royals after trailing by two runs with two outs in the bottom of the seventh inning.
With Cleveland up 7-7 in a game delayed four minutes by a rain shower, the Indians put the tying runs on base with no outs in the seventh inning and dejectingly walked off the field.
But Cabrera stepped up in the eighth inning and sealed the win for Indians rookie Zach McAllister, who gave up Jeremy Gutierrez's tying two-run double in the seventh inning that left scored two runs.
The win for the Indians was helped by Alex Rahden, who made a sprawling stop in shallow right field in the seventh inning, then a steal of third in the eighth by Travis Hafner. Wednesday's win avenged a 9-8 loss on Tuesday.

Yet, this is a market worth engaging. For example, more millennials now own homes than at any point within the last 20 years, and the lifelong housing and rental markets are booming. However, this is not necessarily a reason to relax. Competition in urban markets is particularly stiff, and there is a lot of money flowing into these markets. Additionally, if there remains an out-sized percentage of consumers who aren't adopting technology as much as expected, this is an opportunity to differentiate on informed market analysis.
