Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the Sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago, the Earth is powered by the fusion reactions that occur at the Sun's core (8.) The nuclear magic called stellar nucleosynthesis results in radioactive elements as product of proton-protactin reconverting. The Earth transports about 4 G tons/yr of the radioactive potassium isotopes into the mantle (9.) Formed from gas bubbles and accommodated amongst the minerals, trapped radioactivity can easily remain for billions of years, before collecting impact fluxes and major plate motions accumulate to disrupt their preservation. Over a geological time scale, radioactive decay reradiates the bottled thermal potential when the chemical heat generated is converted to surface heat.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “macrophages,” responsible for swallowing dangerous invaders the body creates to fight harmful growths, succeed in preventing genetic changes to the cells that would otherwise lead to cancer. The fur-coated giants appear to be naturally cancer-resistant due to a mutation that helps turn their gene arsenal against fatal carcinogenic mutations, an international team of scientists wrote in the Journal of Experimental Biology. Their findings were based on research involving captive and wild African savannah elephants.
“One of the few good things to come out of elephant poaching is that we learn about their immunity and the protections their genetics give them for that disease,” said Pauline Ng, a professor of immunology and pathology at Cornell University.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of California—Irvine examined the brains of young adults as they rested in a state they typically report as a feeling of ‘‘being present’’ in ‘‘the now.’’ As a natural state for these participants, it was different from the state in which they were performing a complex problem-solving task. The researchers used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), which measures blood flow to parts of the brain, to evaluate the neural responses associated with this ‘‘cognitively effortful’’ task. The researchers found increased activation of the occipitotemporal sulcus in the brain when a stimulus dictated a person’s whereabouts.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge positions but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute is continuing this series, and more recent charts may be obtained from this source.The ACSYS Historical Ice Chart Archive presents historical sea-ice observations in the Ar

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to be healthier overall. To achieve optimal conditions with large amounts of compost or stored peat moss, you must understand and compensate for large temperature swings during the day. Most commercial sized compost heaps have between 750° and 900° F at up to 150° F in the shadows.
WHAT !? But don't they decay and smell bad? Not if they are stacked carefully, they won't. Compost is ready when it has broken down into a brown, material with soy sauce smell. For the average gardener, 6 months to a year is adequate. If you have more clay in your soil than you like, mix 2 or 3 bags of compost in with your yard when you go ahead and amend it. Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't able to accurately interpret your financial records, it becomes more difficult to make changes and pinpoint wasteful aspects of your business. That's where lean accounting comes in. Lean accounting can be difficult if your business is looking to make major strides. Fortunately, decades of production improvement changes and technology advances have made lean accounting much easier by allowing business leaders to draw up detailed plans to streamline processes.
A difficult problem for many businesses are identifying issues with processes. If you are struggling, XL insurance can offer service and company representatives that will walk you through the process. After a few help sessions and a solid overview of lean accounting, your business will likely find itself much more capable of making effective use of improved resources. Touch accounting also offers its counsel to other businesses looking to better their lean practices.

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing image of families leaping from high windows when they were cut off from escape routes, and tales of people being choked in their beds while smoke poured into their homes, convinced me of one thing: London is no longer home. No, we have become the alien aggressors.
On the eve of the disaster I said to my 15-year-old daughter that moment of history when it becomes clear that your own government has let you down will be unforgettable. This was of course bombs in air-raid shelters used in the 1940s. With such a disaster likely in any large city, we are now on the verge of identifying a mobile command-and-control centre that will be located in each of London’s 32 boroughs.

Take 5: How can we stop being jerky customers?
The customer may not always be right. What are some circumstances where they could be wrong?
In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed a few items on the way to the car, passing by a well-known superstore only a few blocks away. When I entered, a woman waiting to cross the street from her city bus just asked me politely if I minded holding the door for her. This made it possible for her to deboard shortly after me without having to wait for another bus.
Eager for a bag from the adjacent bagger, I realized I forgot a few items. To return inside where they could be waiting when I made my next pass, I circled around and re-entered the store but saw that the bagger was gone. It would seem that an UNEQUAL dynamic had been established: I have to keep going back to a store to shop for items I had already purchased earlier, and I may have to wait 20 minutes for a second round of shopping. Doesn’t this violate the customer happiness code of conduct?

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcing an end to mixed drinks as a part of its decision to ban distilleries from serving food and nonalcoholic beverages.
The agency said it was closing off all distilleries from serving food and nonalcoholic drinks because it was simply too hard to know whether people were being served alcohol or not because the owner has the ability to create his or her own menu.
Alaska has 10 distilleries, and the owner of the distilleries equated the closure to folding and going out of business.
"When it boils down to it's not that they've closed a door. They've closed a window," said Rob Robbins, the founder of Girdwood Glacier Distillery."So we're boxed in and our hands are tied."

Odds are you've watched your favorite show on Netflix enough times to pick up on the overarching plot no matter what episode you're watching. Of course, you can manually choose an episode at "random," but you know that isn't truly random. You could use your mobile phone, pick a show from memory, or even type your preferred genre on its app, but you still know you're really just choosing an episode from the beginning of the show. You just have no clue what it will be.
Now that Netflix believes it has a new approach to showing you online entertainment, you may never have to look at the video again to figure out what episode it is. For $3, users can gain access to the Netflix Genesis program, which will select a random episode for you so you never have to think about what to watch next.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
His Vietnam War book, “Vietnam: A History,” published in 1983, was the 10th volume of the New American Library World Drama Series, a book series edited by the late and longtime Washington Post editor Alice Mayhew. Karnow had a contract for an additional history volume in the series, but the job ended up going to pulp historian James Patterson.
Karnow’s groundbreaking New World History series became a requirement for students, explained Liz Fribenz, executive vice president of Square One Publishers, which publishes the series.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with minimal risk. The diagram shows the various paths, or outcomes, of the decisions that an employee faces while involved in a business activity.
Devising a decision tree is not simply a question of listing possible outcomes, but is best used when organizational members are involved in the process. Decision-tree diagrams determine whether a business provides positive or negative feedback at each choice, with outcomes and resulting impacts. When used as a decision-making tool, these diagrams can show the various possible results that an organization faces.
The best way to come up with a diagram is to turn it into a group activity, even an artful brainstorming session, which would involve everyone contributing to the final product. In the course of this activity, the group brings forth all issues involved rather than relying only on group members who know the organization best. This also makes the group more proactive and

LeBron James scored 27 points and Cleveland entered an elite fraternity of NBA franchises with its 60th win of the season, beating the Detroit Pistons 100-99 on Thursday night to clinch the Central Division title and tie the 1994-95 Houston Rockets' record for fewest losses in NBA history.
The Cavs fell one short of passing the Houston Rockets' standard for fewest losses to declaration in an 82-game season, which was set with a 50-12 record in 1994-95.
The Rockets averaged just 15.2 points more than the Cavs this season to win an NBA-record 63 games. The 82-game mark was first broken by Houston in 1991-92. Before that, champions carried a determination to be so superior that holding the lead for 82 games was the minimum number for being king.

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, in Myanmar's Kachin state, injuring 45 people on Thursday and blocking a nearby motorway.
Fears grew for the 70 workers who were believed still missing almost two days after the landslide, with rescuers using sniffer dogs to try find people thought buried alive.
However, 15 people were eventually dug out from the rubble alive Friday, rescuers said.
However, "our search for the remaining persons is over. We fear that there may be wind caused by the rains on the mountain side and those unaccounted for may have slipped from the mountain side," state police spokesman Tun Tun said, describing Thursday's landslide as a major incident.

This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2018. Outside of a handful of close friends and family members, he was relatively unknown. He was an experimental bassist known in his Chicago scene as the sonic dissector, the artist who could tell when emotions were too strong, forcing changes in personal life. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, 64, won 188 votes out of a possible 193, with none cast against.
No other candidate came forward during secret ballots. Veteran Egyptian diplomat Nabil Elaraby filled the interim post, following the retirement of the Turkish UN chief, Kofi Annan.
Mr Ban had initially been widely expected to step aside and allow China's Li Baodong to take the top job.
But out of 17 votes by UN ambassadors on Friday, Mr Ban received the support of just three of the five Asian and Pacific countries involved in the secret voting process.
Mr Ban is an ethnic Korean who was twice elected the third-highest political official in South Korea.
Correspondents say the second defeat is a humiliation as he steps into a politically perilous second term in office.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2013. The company is working with the community so improvements become available across all open source distributions and not just Hortonworks HDP.
Between the database, Apache Hive and Apache Impala, often separate parallel processing is performed for each query. The result is performance losses because Hive and Impala don’t take advantage of the entire query to increase throughput and utilize other executors.
But now, with Hive, that’s starting to change. In essence, micronauts use the same ‘pipeline’ designated for multiple queries. The intermediate results of the steps get cached and other queries are run in parallel. One example provided in the blog post: there’s a row filter that fetches five percent of the original data. Instead of keep loading that five percent and fetching again every time that row size applies when filtering for another query, fetch the results once and use whenever needed for processing.
The results of Stinger.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses. That trend is changing, however, as three different ERP packages are now available to the open-source crowd:
MySQL suggested to me that developing an effective ERP application is very costly -- and the provider wasn't even a well-versed ERP company.
For example, one key appeal of ERP is the ability to create business rules. Businesses that change course frequently -- a frequent occurrence with fast-turn, transactional companies -- want these rules customized to reflect the structure of the business. A product that locks such rules into stone would likely not work.
Still, MySQL open source provides an intriguing ERP option for a certain segment of the enterprise, namely firms that don't do a lot of business or rely on global partnering.

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the nation’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Obama awarded two present: one with distinction and two with distinction, according to a White House statement.
Forbes editors Robert L. Reischauer and Steve Reilly, who made the long list of amazing stories here on site, are in Washington for the announcement of the winners.
The Presidential Medal of Freedom stretches back to 1775, when it was awarded the Revolutionary War spy Nathan Hale, who warned Washington of a British invasion that never came. Notably, the medal was not awarded during World War II. Obama has chosen ten recipients during his presidency, more than any other president before him.
Other Presidential Civil Justice Awards were awarded as well. Those include Lech Walesa, Holocaust survivor Gennady Friedman and Chief Justice Warren Burger whose awards will be this fall.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the Family and Medical Leave Redesign Act, which covers agencies within the jurisdiction of Maryland.
Leave can now be granted to:
- Seek or attend a meeting or hearing with your doctor, nurse, or social worker.
- Take leave to care for a parent suffering from a serious health condition, or elderly relative. A serious health condition is an illness or injury that requires care for an absence greater than three consecutive, full-days of inpatient care in a hospital, hospice or in-home hospice care, hospice residence, or residential nursing care facility; requiring any level of home care services; or requiring continuing medical treatment or supervision by a healthcare provider.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by West Virginia University researchers for the National Wildlife® Federation, analyzes drinking water quality impacts from the operations and finds gaps in water use monitoring and disclosure.
“Without federal standards or monitoring, watersheds are unprepared to meet the burden of a boom of industrial development like the Marcellus Shale plays,” said Jay Rush, Senior Director of Western New England Water and Drought Watch for the National Wildlife Federation. The study from West Virginia University finds that the necessary water supplies needed to extract the gas do not adequately displace uncertainties in the environmental cost of fracking the Marcellus Shale. With huge amounts of water currently used in Marcellus Shale wells in just the two states of Pennsylvania and West Virginia, It takes 1 million gallons for each well that is fracked. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might otherwise cause them to exit. All have heard of the $1,000 trading rule, whereby one of the rules dictates that if you lose $1,000 things are going badly, and you should shut down your trading until things improve.
However entering the market is only one issue a successful trader has to deal with, which means that the exit or ‘shutdown’ rules are every bit of importance, if they are to eventually turn a profit. Let’s take a look at some of the most critical exit strategies in the forex market today:

An environmental art project launched at a centre for adults with learning difficulties has attracted interest from the upper echelons of the Welsh Assembly.
The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn at the centre have created large sized boats to complement and upgrade three existing collages on display at a building by a busy roundabout on the North Road out of Aberystwyth, designating the area as Wyre Fawr Renewable Energy Park.
The project is expected to be formally launched on Wednesday at a press conference at Dyrys Ystwyth Community Association, Tanygroes, just off the Cardigan Road into Aberystwyth.
Carwyn Jones, Assembly Member for Mid and West Wales has agreed to give his support to the Future Energy Project, which has been six months in the making and involved many ages, abilities and unique talents.
The themes revolve around boats, bridges and water. Nythshire poet Nancy Edwards has written an anthem for the project and Bryn Bledd has composed music to accompany it.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative Islamic establishment, reported the move under a headline that translates to: “‘Machine hall’ is new uranium enrichment site.”
It cited the spokesman of Iran’s atomic agency, Behram Ghaffuri, that the enrichment site is located “30 meters under the ground without any access to the open air, in a geological formation, which makes any kind of aerial attack impossible.”
Iran has not given an official update on the size and the composition of its enriched uranium stockpiles since September.
Three months earlier, the country reached the highest uranium enrichment level ever reached by a civilian nuclear power at its underground Fordo facility.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with UPC Switzerland.
From April 15, Sunrise will enter exclusive talks with UPC on a potential deal that would marry cable company UPC Switzerland's infrastructure with Sunrise's mobile subscriber base.
Yet approval from shareholders seems unlikely to materialise after Raiffeisen Center said it planned to vote against the capital increase.
Raiffeisen Center, which owns 17.34 percent of Sunrise, said it did not like the terms of the proposed capital increase: in November it voted against a previous proposal.
Sunrise, which published a draft of plans to expand its capital, said Raiffeisen Centre is "exceedingly biased" and does not represent the interests of other shareholders.

Spoiler alert: Santa Clause isn’t real—at least, according to these celebrities. For decades, the jolly, red-suited and white-bearded man has ruled the holidays and the imagination of children all over the world. But what happens after you find out he’s actually not real? If you say Santa, celebrating Christmas as a kid is transforming into coping as an adult. Get familiar with what the celebs keep with the story on the other side.
After finding out that their loved ones weren’t the real Santa, many celebrities got candid about their childhood fears about the “truth of Christmas.” Some wondered why parents or grandparents couldn’t be the ones behind their presents, while others decided they longed for a real-life toy running around town or just cooking a feast once a year. “I didn’t like it when my parents told me,” Guy Fieri said for Rolling Stone. There wasn’t much common ground across the board, though. “I was watching ‘A Christmas Story‘ and realized that all the ridiculous things that happened [like breaking into d

"Don't be a "d--- sheep," my father told me this so early and often in my life that I thought the word "sheep" started with a "d." But I didn't miss the counsel that I was not to go along with things just because everyone else (even my friends) did. Just because something was "fashionable" didn't mean it was good, and a fool was anyone who ignored obvious signals. My father may have needed glasses for my subjects, but he often would get it right about what I was doing. I remind myself of his dictum when I see herds of shopping bags with inane messages like "This is What Happy Looks Like" or some other such uplifting piece (none of that stuff was compatible with Du Pont when we were on the other side of the business: whatever those messages said, we were all miserable)." - Malcolm Gladwell
Malcolm Gladwell is a writer, thinker, speaker, and podcaster. He's in conversation with David Brooks about the art of technology.

Why is Christmas pagan and what is an alternative tradition to Christmas one can do instead? originally appeared on Quora: the place to gain and share knowledge, empowering people to learn from others and better understand the world.
Why is Christmas pagan, and what can be done instead? If you love snow, reindeer, Santa, a giant Christmas tree, and presents, what are you supposed to do during the month of August?
There are reasons to look at Christmas as pagan.
Before the middle ages, Christmas was observed during the summer.
However, at the beginning of the 1200’s a needed to unify Western Christianity. Moving Christmas into the winter allowed the churches of the Roman empire to unite, September becoming the break between the spring and summer liturgical seasons, and Christmas being placed with the winter festival.
There are more reasons as to Christmas being pagan, you might check this out on the linked wiki article below.
However, don’t change your tradition because you don’t believe in something before.

A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to the sun.Oli Pettigrew/NASA/JPL-CALTECH
We may only have about a hundred years left to figure out whether the first object from outside our solar system is extraterrestrial in origin.
Or maybe we shouldn't try to confirm that anything else is interstellar at all; it may be more interesting what it isn't.
We went a millennium without a confirmed interstellar object before an unusual pancake-shaped comet called 'Oumuamua came flying through our solar system in October 2017. Because it approached the sun after we recognised it as a comet, we only had three weeks to watch it soar by on the other side.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations is being done on the basis of a greater understanding of circumstances than ever. "Everyone" can now harvest useful data to use as a basis for decision-making; "everyone" is making the best decisions they know how...
Is this, however, really true? That is, to the extent that better data means better decisions, does a better decision mean more profits? The evidence we have to work with is quite limited in scope and does not answer these questions, primarily because anyone who is considering writing a computer program to improve data analysis is unlikely to be willing to bet his finances on it; comparison groups would have to be so large that it is doubtful that any serious research firm will want to put forth the time and energy to make the effort. The questionnaire focused on US history, natural science, the life and social sciences, and civics and government — subjects that are most relevant to making economic choices, planning a college career, and understanding human behavior tasks that are crucial for participating in a modern society. Fewer than 30 percent of the respondents were deemed proficient in basic civic knowledge, nor was US history a strong suit for the study's participants.

According to passenger Carlos Bayone told KING, the extent damage is evaluated and reported to Alaska Airlines.

Howard Dean formally announced on January 11 that he was officially entering the race for chair of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) which will be voted on in early February. The ex-governor of Vermont had been unofficially running for chairman since Mr. Nichols (a trade union official) resigned amidst scandal. Mr. Dean previously ran in the Democratic primaries for president in 2004 and 2008 and ran an influential leadership PAC known as "Democracy for America." The party hoping to come up with a better solution than Kerry and Lieberman quickly nominated Dean, but Kerry and Lieberman's campaigns withdrew from the race. Because the remaining candidates were virtually unknown to party faithful, the race was lost for them by a weekend of late night phone and email campaigning by Nathan Law. Law had worked for Howard Dean in his 2004 presidential campaign and was the campaign manager for Bill White, the Texas House representative who ran for governor in 2006. ROCK CREEK -- From calling in Craig Robinson to host the Hollywood-themed 20th annual gala this Saturday, to implementing a new strategic plan, the Washington County Museum is exploring all avenues in a quest to expand.
"It's about collaboration -- the Board of County Commissioners, the Washington County Museum, the public," says Director Rob McCord. "It's bringing everybody to the table to grow. In order to remain sustainable, we need to continue to grow."
That vision is outlined in a new strategic plan the museum debuted this fall. The plan focuses on expanding the museum's attendance, both in terms of the local demographic and its season, which has historically fallen during the summer months. One concrete next step, McCord pinpoints, is making it easier to partner with local businesses.
"We're not the only folks with good ideas for Washington County -- and they're a part of our strategic plan, which is to leverage outside partnerships," McCord says.
The partnerships and collaboration on last year's Hollywood Gala allowed the Museum to more than double attend

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Didi “trumped” Uber in China on grounds that Didi already claims a near-monopoly of the market in terms of car ownership and second taxi licenses that cause time and cost barriers to new market entrants. Already, the news of Uber’s terminal case in China has seen the price of its shares fall precipitously.
Does this mean Didi is in fact the “winner” of China? The company does have more vehicles on the road at any given moment of the day so it does have an indirect advantage on the number of people per car ratio on the road – but is this is the number for the whole of China? I would imagine that Didi is strongest in the denser urban centres which are quite often the most obvious places for numbers and valuations for taking cases. The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a sixty-year-old power substation along Bank Street. Flames spread to a fuse box nearby, and the fire damaged wiring and other utility equipment. Texas-New Mexico Power, on the scene within minutes, shut off power to the area.
The outage posed a problem for first responders who were near the site as well as for operations at nearby Baylor University Medical Center. About 250 Baylor patients had to be transferred elsewhere, and operations elsewhere were disrupted.
Thirty-three FCSO employees were on a bus near the site when it became obvious there would be no power to turn on air conditioning at The Bridge. Within 11 minutes, all 33 had been loaded onto the bus and taken to the station on Cadiz Street in downtown Dallas.
With no way to let their fellow officers know that they were on their way, thirty-three were no doubt hot and uncomfortable

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both runways by 150 feet and a third runway at JFK's easternmost end to allow the furthest-flung planes from having to turnaround in the air, Governor Andrew Cuomo announced in a statement.
"These are massive and critical upgrades to the infrastructure at JFK International Airport that will help to meet current demand and ensure the airport is prepared as population and tourism continue to grow," he said.
Cuomo said that air traffic control upgrades at JFK along with construction of a state-of-the-art new AirTrain, which currently ferries patrons on trips of at most two miles in length, will slash travel times.

It may be cheaper than driving, but commuting by public transport can still be pretty pricey.
Commuting to work via public transportation is usually cheaper than driving everywhere.
But in these major cities, a monthly pass is pricier than a yearly pass for the same cities.
However, transport companies try and entice customers away from cars with less expensive weekly and daily passes.
Transportation is getting more expensive everywhere you look.
Plenty of articles claim that public transportation is increasingly expensive — but most of these stats, like monthly fares, only compare costs between city-to-city.
In December 2018, Scott Konstanty wrote about the New York Public Transit Index which shows that the Feds spend about $537 million every day on household transportation. While this is high, prices can vary widely.
However, if we compare these prices directly with each other country, we might lose insight into just what we're talking about.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their surroundings and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on that planet seem unthinkable.
Until fairly recently, however, the processes leading to supernal outbursts were a mystery. Now, by putting several different stellar pieces into sharper scrutiny, scientists have finer insights into how supernovas develop. This increased knowledge may prove to be a boon for planet-hunting scientists, who stand to benefit by fruitful early data leading to more productive observations of fainter supernovae many billions of light-years away.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding efforts underway following a phenomena that swept through much of Melanesia.
While the world watched the Olympic action taking place in Rio de Janiero, the cyclone that swept through the islands has so far killed more than 50 people and left a trail of destruction.
Many are yet to reach the aid they desperately need.
Independent relief agency Mercy Relief deployed a team of more than 50 Singaporeans and shipped over more than 60 tons of supplies.

Young people who have spent part of their childhood in care have been invited to special events to mark National Care Leavers' Week.
The events, which are across the country, aims to give care leavers "a voice, a sense of belonging and to let them know that they are loved and wanted".
Poet Lemn Sissay, who's had his own experience of foster care, has said care leavers can be "forged in very different environments".

"Imagine having drawn your first breath as a tiny human into a care environment where you weren't raised to be a human being, but were more often than not abused."

Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political journalism and then shocked the nation when he died of a heart attack last week, was a serious person to the end. He was always smart and thorough with his questions and answers, but even his fans will be surprised to learn how many passionate causes he supports and how high-minded his rationale has been. "I went to the square root. Why ask 'Why?'" he would always laugh when offering an answer that was utterly logical, yet incomplete to the layperson. Those who close newscasts would marvel at how he carried himself on screen (putting his head down and pacing like a caged lion), but those who knew him worried about him at night (knowing him to be a natural radio talker and backroom hustler, they wondered how he survived behind the lectern without cigars and martinis breaking him up day after day after day).

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but it remains a fact as we head into 2010. The bottom line: millions of dollars means millions of votes.
Money does seem to have a growing influence on elections, especially in recent years. Political donations by wealthy individuals and corporations reached nearly $2.5 billion spent on federal races in 2006, according to a Center for Responsive Politics report. The IU Political and Civic Engagement Program also reported in 2006 that more than 2.5 million fewer people voted for president in 2000 than in 1988.
The problem, Dugi said, is that fewer poor are voting today than were able to do so by mail. Voting has become a cash nexus in which the rich and well connected worry less about the needs of a person who may not be able to mail in their ballot.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“Concussion” means a temporary loss of neurologic function following head trauma, often resulting from a blow or jolt to the head, face, neck or body. Symptoms usually include headache, dizziness, balance and speech issues, and memory lapses, among other things, the CDC says.
According to the CDC, nearly one-third of all boys and girls — ages five to 14 — had a visit to the doctor because of a head injury. Of those about one-third were concussions.

In 2011, a group of Chinese nationals came to my farm in South Dakota. They sampled the soil, plowed, fertilized and planted acres of South Dakota land. Now they reap profits for their personal gain. I can’t tell you their names and some of the names you’ll hear here. If I did, they could be banned from agricultural export opportunities in the future. UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to distributed mountaintop or rural locations to improve resilience during winter weather. They expect to produce a prototype within one year with the help of a $5.9 million grant from the U.S. Department of Energy.
The lead researchers on this project are our very own Fafa Dong, Assistant Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering and Massimo Felici, Staff research scientist in Fuel Cell Research Center in Burton Technology Center.
Read the article about this project here.
To learn more about Dong’s research program, please visit her website.
To learn more about Felici’s research, please visit his website.
To learn more about our renewable energy and sustainability-related research, please see our profile.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video to explain his philosophy.
That selflessness was borne out of experimentation. For years, Smith has been experimenting with different ways to get the word out about his work, and the 2009 book itself was an exploration in storytelling: The book was printed with part of it missing, and the reader was challenged to "fill in the blank" and make something out of the book (Smith offers downloadable decks of cards and a step-by-step manual).
Will people take advantage of today's giveaway? Maybe, but only if you invite them, says Smith. "Invite people to share, particularly the ones that aren't going to buy your book."

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature throughout the formative early years of his life, and throughout his 72-year lifetime he made 74 extended trips into the wild, introducing tens of thousands of hikers and pilgrims to U.S. National Parks. Muir, a jumble of seemingly contradictory ideas and beliefs, fell in and out of scientific disciplines throughout his life and he made seminal contributions to many ecological discoveries and conversations that connect people to nature today. “The Unruly Mystic” features author Katie Hall and author and naturalist Michael Cheng. So you're renting a car? It's no big deal, unless something goes wrong. Here's a checklist based on our own experiences and on the rental cars we've seen in our shop lately.
Rental cars can be a big commitment these days and fraud has been known to occur, so be sure that the vehicle matches the one being offered. Let the rental agent take you to see the vehicle yourself just to be sure it's the same model you're renting, and be sure to get a picture with your phone.
2. Meet all required state-required inspections.
Many Pennsylvania counties require car rentals to be inspected every 30 days. Check out the county requirements and make sure the vehicle is up-to-date. Shockingly, these state-required inspections don't include a lot of real safety checks, which is something to keep in mind if the rental company drops off the vehicle without a standard maintenance check. Also, check your liquid fill levels with the owner's manual and bring along all the necessary owner's manuals and operating manuals with you.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with ways to describe their changing colours, and colours in general – for instance, using colourful paint chips to describe sunsets. My mother noticed a strong interest in colour around that time and gifted me a photography book: The Colour Process by Rudolf F. X. D\}"Ve. I was about 8 years old. This triggered my interest in photography and I’ve loved it ever since, though I didn’t take up colour seriously until I was in my teens. I’ve tried to make a discipline of staring at colour for a week, once it’s had time to sink in. I can honestly say that many forms of colour dance and weave around me, create movement and rhythm and speak to my imagination.

What are the lessons we can draw from the removal of leavened foods, and the bland crackers we eat for a full week?
Sometimes those challenging moments, when we feel that we have been flattened and/or that God has shamed us, actually become instruments in His resurrecting us. They contain His grace for us if we allow ourselves to be bent.
God wanted to redirect Paul’s focus to the basics, returning him to the core truths about faith. They harken directly back to Moses’ time. They are part of what the Jews had already received. They are not new, they are not advanced, and they are not insignificant. They are part of the foundation upon which the whole building (our faith) rests.
To God, it was a big deal. To God, it always is. To Paul, maybe not so much. To us, we need to ask whether we pass God’s test of faith and action. God wants mature fruit, not assumptions, regarding what the importance is to Him of our faith statement. Our faith is also leavened by our thoughts, our words, our actions

What's More Important: Your Product Or Proof-Of-Concept?
I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once they get over the awkwardness that attendants are expected to behave like undercover valley talent scouts, the founders quickly voice their mission around what they want to build.
What they typically don't mention is to actually get there, they need a product, and often a product that tests out the market and validates their feedback. I'm increasingly being reminded by both VCs and entrepreneurs that without proof of concept a company stalls. And, this applies whether your scale-up is a freemium business, a SaaS, a consumer product, or some data-driven Internet play.
I went out and capturing a couple of thoughts around this, from startups to VCs to blog readers.

Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Raffaele Grillo of INAF-Osservatorio Astronomico di Palermo, in Italy has detected a highly distorted, extragalactic radio source at the edge of a galaxy group 630 million light years from Earth. The new planetary nebula, RCW 109, is of special interest to scientists as this is the first example where an expanding radio bubble is known and adds to the understanding of how these objects evolve.

Mike Tyson is historically attributed the observation along the lines of ‘everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth’.
A thought of this nature may have occurred to one or two home spectators on Saturday when West Ham were awarded a penalty. Mason Jimi (confidently celebrating), stepped up and placed the ball on the penalty spot. Our opponents prepared to ‘play the ball’. Mason, with outward facing feet, took a few extra steps back to one side of the spot. He waved a hand at his right side then to his left. He grinned wildly at nothing in particular. He took a deep breath and let it out forcefully. It was the famous “whatever I’m going to do next doesn’t bear thinking about …” breath. He assumed a mock trail position, with hands in the air and head down.
Part Arsenal, part diva and part Alan Partridge, he was now fully committed.

Two homegrown musicals symbolize opposite ends of theater here. Andrew Lloyd Webber - the world's most bankable composer - has opened "The Woman in White," drawn from a novel of Victorian morality. By contrast, Beng Ahluwalia has opened the zany and original "Company of Strangers" - a musical without the strings. While both survive in salt water, the question for Rangoon is: Are they both winners? Mindful of the surge in expat ticket sales, the specialist ensembles have become confident. Stylized musicals and with broaching subjects, both works face the hard-core locals head-on. Who will come? Who won't?

Following a weekend of uncertainty, frantic negotiations and enough finger pointing and partisan recriminations to last us through the middle of the century, the U.S. Senate on Monday voted 81-18 to approve President Bush’s handling of the nation’s economy.
The President’s bill offered a fairly quick infusion to the banking system, more than a trillion dollars in loans that will offer stability and help all but the weakest banks to weather the storm. The plan also included some measures to address growing foreclosures and help people in trouble with loans.
What Senate Democrats (and other critics) objected to was what the proposal did not include-something to help those Americans who are most at risk in the current multi-dimensional economic disaster.
The Senate bill also includes billions of dollars to overhaul lobbying rules, and will require companies wanting to lobby the government to obtain permission one year in advance, while banning lobbyists from auditing firms that are clients for five years after retiring. This Is What It's Like To Be A Syrian Refugee Child In Lebanon.
I asked 12 young aspiring journalists who have fled the war in Syria three different questions about what their life is like now, and what their hopes are for the future.
“We went to our house in Syria, and it was destroyed.”
“Unfortunately my grandfather was killed.”
“We used to live in Syria…we came to Lebanon after our father was wounded in one of the attacks.”
Welcome to the street journalism project, #OurStreets.
I was in Lebanon for a week in March to work with an American charity (The Syria Relief Fund) to interview refugee children and their families and talk about daily life. They would write down their answers to three questions after looking through a camera lens and take a photo.
These three questions are about what their life is like now (recently migrated to Lebanon on average 6 months ago), what they miss from Syria, and what they hoped for in the future. The children often chose to write in English, but I would also help them

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app, consumers want access to these innovations with their wallets, to gadgets in their pockets, and to experiences in their homes.
However, businesses and consumers also want to know they’re interacting with trusted tools, products, and experiences – and industry regulations are a critical way to instil trust.
When regulations are created using risk-based methods, they can help build trust by giving businesses the confidence that their innovations will meet regulatory requirements, without unnecessarily blocking their progress. But regulators often struggle to channel their expert knowledge in faster, and leaner ways with lower overall costs. Consequently, it can take months to complete the sign-off and approval process to bring new innovations to market.

Harry Turner had his surgery in 1969

As for the Saudis?

Legislators are considering the establishment of a strategic environmental assessment system to evaluate the consequences of governmental policies and planning on the environment and to ensure sustainable development in the country.
Such a system will be legalized by a decree, which will directly enter into force after its approval, said Ali Kamal, chairman of the Egyptian Atomic Energy Commission, during the conference “Engineering Days” organized by Misr Universities’ Consortium in Sharm El-Sheikh.

President Anwar al-Sadat of Egypt has broken all relations with Syria, Libya, Algeria and South Yemen.
He has ordered their diplomats to leave Egypt within 24 hours and recalled his envoys from the four countries.
Mr Sadat's move came as he greeted the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, on his visit to Egypt yesterday.
Mr Shevardnadze is believed to have asked for the four countries to be expelled from the United Nations by Egypt, which has the Security Council veto.
Palestinian problem

The European Union won’t require its member countries to ban Huawei from their wireless networks, despite the U.S.’s warning that the Chinese tech giant poses an intelligence threat. Cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright reacts to the news.
According to Europe’s top economic official, European Union member countries will decide what level of access they want to grant Chinese tech giant Huawei.
The warning is in stark contrast to the Trump administration’s announcement last month that the Chinese telecom manufacturer poses a threat to national security, given that Huawei is effectively controlled by the communist Chinese government.
This decision could be considered somewhat of a threat to U.S.-China trade relations as nations will not push further away from China.

ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
Temperatures reach 1,572°C and hold for up to several hours before they become inert rock.
The big green fireball was captured by James Nilson in Northern California, USA, and was about 35,000 miles away from Earth at that point.
Energetic light from the Swift-Tuttle comet lights the night sky with fallen debris on August 12, 1993. It moves along the E texture of the Milky Way along this strip skimming the constellations Perseus, Cassiopeia and Cepheus toward northern skies.
He said he spotted the meteor four days before the expected peak resulting from Perseid meteor shower.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include more links, hashtags, and content. According to Twitter, over 250,000 tweets have been retweeted with comment since the pilot phase of testing took place last June.
So far, 20 percent to 25 percent of respondents in Twitter’s pilot test of the feature were engaging the retweeted tweets.

Trade turnover between Russia and its second largest trade partner, Germany, increased 8.4 percent and reached nearly €62 billion ($70 billion) in 2018 compared to previous year, according to the German trade lobby. This was Germany’s biggest export success this year, after the country had surpassed most of its rivals in 2018. Russia thus shared first place with France with respective export of €89 billion, inheriting the leading position from number two country for Germany, the US, with €56 billion.
In 2018, Russia overtook courted Netherlands with regard to imports, as Germany’s imports from Russia increased by 23.3 percent to €39.6 billion. Germany’s share in Russian trade is estimated to be about 21 percent and is expected to increase.

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct under General Pinochet was "the worst thing that happened in Chile".
BBC Latin America analyst Stephen Gibbs says the statement is an effort to heal a faultline that has fractured Chilean society since General Pinochet, 17 years after his rule, was finally sent to jail 25 years ago.
The Supreme Judicial Council called the period "one of the darkest moments in our republic".
It is the first time the judiciary as a whole has acknowledged that many of its members were "intellectual authors" of atrocities committed under General Pinochet.
In its 40-page statement, the high-ranking council said they wanted to establish "the moral rectitude which should guide our judicial actions".

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Nashville after undergoing surgery for a fall. He was 71.
Reed, who was made an official historian of the Cherokee people in 2008, had just left an awards show in Los Angeles on Saturday when he fell on the cold tarmac of the airport and suffered brain trauma and broken ribs. He returned to the airport with police Monday to retrieve a forgotten trunk and was shown to a private room, where he died early Monday, according to son, Matthew Reed.
Reed first came to Nashville to land a record deal, but then settled in to a growing list of acting roles. A dying man in Nebraska was comforted by 3,500 strangers he never knew as his family kicked off the #SkyBluePink campaign after he was diagnosed with lung cancer.
Brian Curtis, a Nebraska native, launched the idea as a “anything with a heartbeat in it” homage to all cancer victims. After he posted about his idea, it took off like wildfire.
Curtis, 53, has worked with several cancer groups in the past and came up with idea for strangers to dye their hair blue and pink for the cause, too.
He started seeing a doctor in June and by September, doctors told him it’s spread throughout his body.

LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as authorities try to contain a surge in malaria deaths.
Malaria cases jumped nearly 25 percent in 2018 to 563,307 from a year earlier, the Zambian government said. Nearly 70 percent of all cases were recorded in the capital Lusaka where Kansai Plascon is based.
Zambia’s environment minister Bettye M. Kabamata lifted a 25-year ban on human malaria-resistant mosquito releases.
She said the initiative would involve releasing selective insects into areas near selected populations while spraying remote reserves.
Malaria killed 458 people in Zambia last year against 51 the year prior, according to a government report published last month.

Consultant recommends candidates from Miami, Colorado and New Jersey from among 28 applicants.
A consultant is recommending that Brevard County commissioners interview three candidates for consideration as the next county manager.
Daniel Alfonso, a partner with the higher-education consultancy firm Reynolds Ashford & Associates, released a 24-page report and a video following months of public input, an online survey, a community survey and two focus groups led by the internationally known consultant.
Alfonso’s report including his eight-page biographies about each candidate is being released Oct. 29. He is recommending that the commissioners interview the three applicants. The recommendations do not come with ratings.
The three recommended candidates are: Ben Green, chief of staff in Miami and previously deputy city manager in Orlando; Jim Dinneen, assistant city administrator in Colorado Springs and to Mayor Michael Hancock; and Roger Cressey, an official in New Jersey’s Department of Health and Personnel Services and previously a special advisor to Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick and acting U.S. Homeland Security Secretary from 2009

The Lowcountry was spared of Hurricane Irene’s wrath last week, but Sun City took the storm seriously and was prepared to batten down the hatches if the threat of a hurricane hitting the area became worse than anticipated. The weather gods put our region in good hands and we are happy to report the following:
– There were no evacuations
– There were no power outages
– There were no flooding events in any of the Lowcountry’s communities
– The relocations center provided shelter for 28 residents
– Golf carts were able to operate
We encourage our residents to practice safety at all times, but especially during a storm. Winds with a plan can be very dangerous people! If you do not feel comfortable during an inclement weather event, do not hesitate to call our security desk by dialing 312. In cases of a true emergency feel free to call 911. The complex’s Security personnel are all certified and well equipped to handle security issues in your home.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to accept prices well below that of other crops, according to one exporter.
Close to half of Tanzania’s production for the 2016/17 season will face frustration in the coming months as domestic demand falls away with the end of the major religious festivities, Ramadan and Eid, as well as the Christmas and New Year periods which peak in late December.
Dattatray K Patil, chief executive of Patil Enterprises, said exports of cashew nuts had come to an almost total halt this season and they had seen no shipments above low double digits for months.

Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach includes more than 250 million users. The deal also merges Verizon’s Go90 mobile video business, which has 15 million users and is reportedly on the verge of exhausting its $2.6 billion in cable network buys, with AOL, which has the online version of HBO on its network. Indeed, some are speculating that Go90 may return huge profits to investors via this acquisition. This move would constitute Verizon’s largest ever purchase.
Joe Rath and Jay Pestrichaud will lead the integration and deployment of AOL and the future Verizon-AOL platforms.
Ross Gillia will be Senior VP of Video, with oversight of Verizon’s pay-TV business, OTT video business and content initiatives.

Examining the Recent Silver Rally, Will It Last?
Silver had a big day on February 28 th as it sharply rose by 4.5% - the sharpest gain for silver since January 31 st , 2019 .
While gold made its move from a technical perspective three weeks ago, silver has been somewhat more slow as it took a bit longer for major technical resistance levels to be broken.
The move in silver was most notable given this long stable price action since mid to late 2018 and while the price level bands remained quite oscillatory over this nearly two year period, the physical demand for silver at retail shops also remained relatively modest. The term 'tough markets' is a notorious phrase for gold and silver investors who have had to deal with a long term consolidation in prices, weak store sales and peak silver sales during the holiday retail shopping season - usually the strongest time of the year for buying the precious metals.

As classes let out in Searcy, Ark., on Tuesday, and students scattered across neighborhoods, a seventh-grader in the Riverview School District noticed something that stopped him in his tracks. He was taking a shortcut to the grocery store, with his mother and two sisters, when he spied the name "Isis" etched across his neighbor's house. Again. His neighbor had previously listed her house for sale under the name Isis.
When asked by his mother about the name, he learned the story. "She wants to be known as Isis," the mother explained. "Right now she's going under fire and that's a powerful kick in the face."
The 7-year-old, turned 9 recently, has since maintained that the name "has evil intentions." On Thursday he took to the microphone and used his name and platform to protest the naming. Michael Basilyan, Senior Program Manager from the Bing Content Quality Team, shared a nice set of details on the Bing blog this morning about the content quality factors considered in their web search algorithm.
They focus on two main criteria: E-A-T (expertise, authority, trust) & T-A-T (topic, authority, trustabily) -- I guess they don't trust the SEO Saviors at Google and instead opt for making bulletins themselves. :)
For example, if a doctor modifies their profile so they can offer prescriptions (which they can't do UNTIL the profile is modified) suddenly the organic search engine rankings on Bing for you will tank.
There are no explanations in this post from Bing, but some experts argue that it's a glaring attempt on Bing's side at creating their version of Google Panda.

LITTLE more than 18 months ago, Timothy Riley was a happy, active young man.
But a diagnosis of leukodystrophy - a rare degenerative disease that affects around one in a million people - changed that.
Now 17, his condition means his nervous system is crumbling and he is completely unable to walk unaided and often needs to be helped to breathe. He is undergoing 24/7 care at Royal Manchester Children's Hospital.
Not long ago his mother Carol, 44, was told that her son might only have two or three more years left in his life.
But now Timothy is facing an even darker future.
‘They are fighting a rearguard action,’ said Mrs Riley, a respiratory nurse who grew up in Bracebridge Heath. ‘They don't know how his condition is progressing. Something blighting and destroying his bones by an undetectable timebomb, that's what Tim is living with.’

Will the GDPR affect your business?
Story From LBMC: GDPR compliance: Will the EU’s new data regulation affect your business?
Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares with the EU’s Internet Economy Board on its website, “The GDPR regulates the personal data of EU citizens for monitoring and direct marketing,” requiring that companies tell EU citizens the purposes for data collection and inform them of their rights in relation to certain processing activities of that data. With the typical large volume of data users, the GDPR will and has been signed by industry giants like Google and Facebook, but also corporate behemoths like Equifax and Match.com. The National won big at the 60th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night.
The Brooklyn-based, Cincinnati-bred group won Best Alternative Music Album for "Sleep Well Beast."
The National picked up their first Grammy Award on Sunday night from the 60th annual ceremony. In all, the group was nominated for seven awards -- including the top titlish categories of Song and Album of the Year -- and came away with two, picking up Best Alternative Music Album for "Sleep Well Beast" and Best Rock Song for "The System Only Dreams in Total Darkness," which features Arcade Fire's Richard Reed Parrish.
As Music Time in A+E previously reported, it was not a bad evening for the band, though perhaps a disappointment because of the number of nominations the group received.

My favourite indicator of market breath, the McClennan Summation Index, is finally beginning to get to a level where it is becoming interesting. A move into negative territory, though some ways to go, will herald the probability of a meaningful correction.
For that market strength needs to continue in the mean time. It isn’t really likely that we see a dip of more than several points from here, but I still feel that a couple of months movement to the upside is needed before we see anything meaningful. As I’ve said already, it isn’t like this is to the moon, but more a steady climb with a fairly tight consolidation range. This is supportive of market moves of a couple of per cent, but with the tone tending in the direction of less certainty of these gains persisting towards the intermediate zone of the charts, to a maximum of five per cent, conditions aren’t quite ideal for the rampant price gains demanded of late.

CHATHAM — Glenwood High School’s principal has given notice that he will resign June 30 after one year on the job.
Russell Tepen, 50, whose resignation was approved Thursday night by the Chatham school board, told the Morris Daily Herald Friday that it was the right decision for himself, his family and the students and staff at the small high school on Route 181.
Mr. Tepen said that family needs drove his decision and that his extended family includes students and staff members.
“I love the kids and the staff at Glenwood and it is very hard for me to leave, but I feel like if I stayed here what I am doing right now, it would consume me,” said Mr. Tepen. “I feel strongly about elementary education and needed to go to that direction to support and maintain my sanity.”
Raul Andre, 55, who has been Glenwood High School’s associate principal for the last seven years, will succeed Mr. Tepen on July 1 as principal.

Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — its ancient narrow streets and vintage, weathered white buildings — and many of its 63 lives into a state of absolute disarray.
Water and mud gushed through every orifice available, forcing dozens of residents into higher ground. Of those taken up the mountainside, only 18 made it out.
But that’s not how the story will end, quite the opposite, in fact.
In preparations to rebuild, residents will use the opportunity to improve city planning measures and engineering, to refurbish damaged historic areas and businesses and — if the outpouring of support witnessed around the world is any indication — to reshape destination awareness as a much greater hub for arts, culture and Gallo wine.

BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to terrorize the country’s bitter Cold War-era rival.
That rival was the Soviet Union, and its arsenal. So China only wanted enough usable nuclear warheads that, if lost in a conflict, it could produce new ones to erase the setback.
But since then, that calculus has changed in profound ways. Gone are the days of the Soviets — and now China itself — developing nuclear weapons essentially for deterrence alone. The Chinese are also ruthlessly competitive power-mongers seeking to exploit China’s exponential rise on the world stage. This quest makes us better targets than the U.S.S.R. ever did.

Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done on the site. And he used to refer to the Friendster Web site as the first Internet, until Friendster was replaced by MySpace as the network to beat.
Kerner is always illuminating and I can highly recommend following his updates on the Web — I recently did a Twitter-based live interview with him about Facebook. Anyway, Kerner raised some interesting points in the past week about how the end-to-end mentality of emerging social communications networks (I have my own categories for these things) is inevitably outmoded by the discipline and concern for accuracy that these evolve into. There is an element of truth, he points out, to the report this week about how an exodus of writers was beginning at the Atlantic Monthly. The Wildcats (6-1) claimed an Atlantic Coast Conference title and ended the Wolverines' (7-0) 11-game winning streak. But it was one of Northwestern's toughest games and Maryland won its only ACC title nearly a century ago.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria by using small molecules already found within them.
Antibiotics treat a variety of conditions, but their overuse can have side effects in the gut including stomach aches, cramping and diarrhea. Antibiotic-associated diarrhea is a condition caused by disruption of good bacteria in the gut and can result in over $3.5 billion lost to the US economy each year.
Scientists have now discovered that some species of good bacteria produce potent chemical substances, such as bacillomycin, that can protect other beneficial bacteria and help them survive exposure to antibiotics.
They discovered that Bacillus cereus bacteria produce bacillomycin, a compound similar to hundreds of bacillomycin-like compounds found within bacteria.
However, bacteria are constantly adapting

"The kids walked to Wheatley, and I wanted to be as close to my kids and their parents as possible, where I could be part of the community," Hamilton said.
Choosing school

Notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne is being investigated for a Facebook comment poking fun at last week's terror attacks.
French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.
Dieudonné was a major figure in France’s “Charlie Hebdo” crackdown
Dieudonné posted a photograph on Facebook, showing two terrorists dressed in camouflage edge around a police officer with his hand raised showing a white flag. The officer’s head is missing.
He wrote, “I recognize this picture. Where are the copies?”, according to Reuters.
In the post, he also sarcastically congratulated President Francois Hollande on his “shock, dismay and sadness” over the murderous raid that left 12 people dead and 10 wounded at the offices of Charlie Hebdo, the magazine satirist Stephane Charbonnier who founded the tabloid and his colleagues have consistently mocked Islam.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrochloride (ritalin) dosing groups: low (5 mg), medium (10 mg) and high (20 mg). Each group received 15 mg of methylphenidate in the morning (reservoir, placebo group) and then 5 mg during the afternoon (placebo, methylphenidate group). There was single administration of methylphenidate during the morning of the first and the third day and during the evening of day five. Seven male subjects with diagnosed diagnosis of hyperactivity received the drug and were subsequently tested. For six of these subjects, there was a significant difference in the methylphenidate group and in the placebo, methylphenidate during the evening. WHAT would you do if you came upon a fight between a violent attacker and a weaker victim? Would you intervene? Go for help? Or merely join the crowd of onlookers? Now that you’ve determined your answer, you can begin figuring out the best way to interact during a potentially violent encounter.
We are an emotional species, or, as U.S. Congressman Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) illustrates, we have a “Lizard Brain,” which is always on alert and constantly triggering our limbic system, our emotional center.
Our emotional center can quickly override our logic center, and this concussion can lead a person to inaction when confronted with a violent attack.
Raney teaches the concept of “assess, act, alert” and how this systematic action can help counter the extra-rational response we often find in moments like these.
Teens must be taught to start at the end. That is, in a varying array of potentially violent situations, how do they end it?
They must be taught the “A” point — the point of awareness — often begins at the end

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- General Electric Co. shook the U.S. stock market Friday, reporting a 6% drop in first-quarter net profit -- largely over trouble in its financial-services businesses -- that fell below expectations. But despite the bad quarter on Wall Street, the maker of locomotives and aircraft engines suggested it will be firing on all cylinders when the year is done.
GE said the downturn is beginning to hit certain businesses -- banking, auto finance and commercial services -- while benefiting from growth in emerging markets. This is in contrast to GE's main rival, 3M Co., which made gains on emerging markets for the quarter, but had several disappointing sectors at home. GE's relative waffling could weigh on the Dow Industrials, which have already underperformed during 2008.

Two separate tragedies on opposite sides of the country resulted in one awful, violent day. Yesterday 11 people died in two car crashes involving drivers speeding the wrong way. In Florida, an SUV driving against traffic hit a minivan and as it did, a tree fell down around 6:30 PM in Broward County. Six people died and eight were injured. And 3.5 hours later at the same time here in El Paso, a man driving against traffic in a four-mile stretch on Interstate 10 hit two vehicles. All three passengers, a 17 and 41 year old man and a woman, 61, died at the scene and a passenger in the first passenger vehicle was not hurt. Investigators say the man was speeding at an estimated 90 miles an hour in a 65 mile an hour zone.
Authorities in the crash with the SUV are still trying to determine who was driving at the time and whether or not speed would have been a factor. Although, no matter what, it’s still pretty scary to think fast down on a busy highway in a four mile stretch.

A JEALOUS woman who posed as fake police officers to control her ex-boyfriend and to even stop him from seeing other women has been jailed.
Lauren Adderley, 21, used "sophisticated" activities to manipulate her ex-boyfriend Matthew Nurun John and make it seem like he had been arrested and was in custody via social media postings, and put him under surveillance, according to reports.
The offences happened from February to October this year, when Adderley lived in a property next to John in Fitzroy.
Adderley used spy techniques, including tailing John and analysing the phone dates, documents, contacts and messages, the Herald Sun reported.
For example she used her ex-boyfriend’s mobile number to impersonate a constable who had issued him with a general safety warning concerning child predators before claiming his smartphone had been seized. She then posted false photos to a dating website using the same mobile number to make it appear John was in custody on child pornography and stalking charges. Fredericka Wagner has pleaded not guilty to three charges of aggravated murder in a death penalty case that includes five adult family members and the family dog. Her motion to dismiss the charge was filed Friday in Pike County court.
Authorities accuse 53-year-old Wagner, believed to have killed her mother and three siblings in April 2016, of trying to help boyfriend William Bias expose what he believed was an international child sex-trafficking ring conspiracy. Prosecutors maintain it was a ruse to deflect blame for the killings.
Recordings of Wagner and Bias may be key to understanding the case. The judge sealed 30 hours of recordings Bias made of Wagner calling his lawyer in March. The judge cleared Bias' attorney to play the recordings to a grand jury.
